Those people do not have the savings and the opportunities that some of the spivs opposite have had and have taken for granted throughout their whole lives.

speech.para: We heard that this was well thought through. The opposition leader exposed that farce today in the parliament with two documents. The reform has been so well thought through that they printed tens of thousands of copies of a document but then had to pulp them because their pollsters and spin doctors, who they are paying millions of dollars—Liberal Party friends—advised them: ‘It’s probably not a good idea just to say “A simpler national workplace relations system for Australia”. We need to add the word “fairer”.’ Why did they need to get advice to add the word ‘fairer’? Because the concept of fairness is anathema to those opposite. The concept of equality, the concept of a fair go, is something that they oppose and just do not get. They hate workers, when it comes down to it. They hate average Australians. They think that the people they are elected here to represent—those people of privilege—are the only people who deserve representation in this parliament.

We saw it perhaps best here from the member for Gippsland. The member for Gippsland has for three days in a row got dorothy dixers in which he has spoken about agricultural awards, shop assistants and the average decent, hardworking Australians who keep this country going, in pejorative terms. He has actually had the hide to criticise payments in awards for personal contributions at the workplace level for rural workers who provide a horse for the benefit of themselves and their employer. That is seen by the minister as something that is hilarious. That has got a run for three days in a row, as it is so strange and odd that this would be included in awards!
But the minister, of all people—given that he used to be a minister and then had to resign and pay back $9,000 of taxpayers’ money over travel allowance—

talk.start.para: —Shame! Shame—and he’s now a minister.
—The member for Wills has been warned and should know the rules.

—should be very conscious of the complex arrangements that come in our awards that we have to sign off on every month. Just as workers have in their awards transport entitlements, so do we, and ours are pretty generous. If the member for Gippsland drives his car from Sale in Victoria to Parliament House, he gets 522 times 63c—$328.86—each way. That is a total of $328.86 for five or six hours work, not bad money in the kick—something that the minister knows a lot about when it comes to public money. But, when he gets here, the minister has to sign off the registry to prove that he was here. He then has to reconcile it. There are documents the thickness of a telephone book that we have to comply with in what is essentially the equivalent of our award. But there is one difference between our conditions and the conditions of the average worker: this man, who has more wealth than probably every shop assistant in Australia combined, begrudges elements in awards such as $5. He begrudges $5 going to an average worker, which exposes, really, what the government are about.

speech.para: The member for Goldstein talks about how well the economy is going under this government. They speak about the flexibility that is there. Of course it is there, because the Hawke and Keating Labor governments made sure through their industrial relations reform—which was all about enterprise bargaining and making sure that productivity was a key to wage increases—that the economy they inherited would go well. But this government have it confused. They have confused non-unionism with anti-unionism. It is true that unionism in this country has fallen to about one in four in the work force. They have thought this through and thought, ‘That means everyone hates unions.’ Not true. Decent, hardworking Australians know that they want a safety net. They want an Industrial Relations Commission. They might not even know who are members of their union. We have all had workers turn up to our electorate offices and say, ‘I need assistance. I’ve copped a raw deal off the boss.’ The first thing you say to them is, ‘Have you gone to your union?’ They say, ‘I’m not really a member—but I would like to join.’ And you know what they do? They do just that—join. Part of the culture in this country is knowing that trade unions exist and will be there for those who need them. Part of the culture of the great Australian Labor Party that we will not walk away from is our connection with the trade union movement, something that we are proud of.

The government in its documents has really exposed what it is about. This is a government that would construct an industrial relations system in which ‘fairer’ just does not figure, in which ‘fairer’ is an afterthought. This is also a government which has been exposed by these documents. What has it taken out of the documents? It has taken out ‘your existing award conditions protected by law’.

Can you imagine the setting? In the minister’s office, the document comes through—glossy, paid for as part of the $100 million spend. The minister or one of his advisers gets it and reads: your existing award conditions protected by law. ‘We can’t really say that because we’re not doing it. We’d better take that out.’ Then they have a look and read: preserving key award conditions. ‘Well, we’re not really going to do that either. We’d better take that out.’ Then they have a look and see: terms and conditions in existing agreements will be protected. ‘We’re not going to do that either, so we’d better take that out.’

What this document exposes—not a piece of propaganda from the ACTU or the ALP, but a document from the government, paid for by the Australian taxpayer—is what this government is really about: ripping the guts out of fairness in the Australian system. Fairness characterises us as a nation. We use it throughout our language: ‘fair dinkum’, ‘fair go’. We can lose the Ashes and think, ‘That’s all right, because it was about time the Poms won.’ We have as part of our culture fairness before the law. The rights of trade unions are a core part of that. The fact is the government has just got this wrong. It knows it has got it wrong because its $100 million propaganda campaign has been exposed as being illegal. The AEC wrote to the minister today saying just that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Out of the mouth of the member for Grayndler is the MPI condemned. Where was the member for Grayndler’s reference, throughout his entire diatribe, to investing in skilling the Australian work force? The Labor Party are simply using what has happened this week for political opportunism, and they have been told to do so by the union movement. They are running scared of the union movement and they must oppose. This is in total contrast to our position back in 1993. In their contributions, the member for Grayndler and the Leader of the Opposition referred to the former Prime Minister Paul Keating and what he did. I am glad they did that, because it stands in stark contrast. The actions of our party when we were in opposition stand in stark contrast to the actions of the ALP at the moment, now they are in opposition.

speech.para: The reform process that is taking place at the moment in Australia is very much an evolutionary one. It started in 1993. We saw the second wave of reforms in 1996 and we are now seeing a third wave of reforms taking place in 2005. When Paul Keating introduced that first wave he was opposed by the union movement. But do you know who supported him? The opposition supported the moves, at that time, to make changes. Obviously we felt that he had not gone far enough—we would have liked him to have gone a bit further—but we still supported him. So the claims of the high and mighty on the other side that what we have today is because of their changes in 1993—that the fruits of those changes are what we are benefiting from—are pure hypocrisy.
Back in 1993 the former Prime Minister was very prophetic. He said of the industrial relations system in this country:

quote.para: ... let me describe the model of industrial relations we are working towards. It is a model which places ... emphasis on bargaining at the workplace level within a framework of minimum standards provided by arbitral tribunals. Over time the safety net would inevitably become simpler. We would have fewer awards, with fewer clauses ... We need to find a way of extending the coverage of agreements from being add-ons to awards ... to being full substitutes for awards.

speech.para: The statement made by Paul Keating that ‘we need to find a way of extending the coverage of agreements from being add-ons to awards to being full substitutes for awards’ is precisely where we are today. What Paul Keating advocated back in 1993, at the beginning of the reform process, is exactly what is happening today. In this third stage of reforms we are seeking to make agreements full substitutes for the choking award based system. Do we receive any support from the ALP? No. Do we receive any support from the union movement? No, of course not. We are not surprised by the union movement’s opposition to this. They opposed the reforms then and they oppose them now. The difference is that they now have their comrades, those on the other side, who will do their bidding to avoid risking preselections and hard-earned financial support come the next election.

The MPI this afternoon has been confused with a censure motion. The member for Grayndler’s speech epitomised that fact. The argument today has been based on an attack on the government’s advertising campaign. I can only wonder what it is that the opposition is asking us to do. Is it asking us not to inform the Australian public of one of the major reform programs undertaken by this government? It is an advertising campaign—an information campaign—to inform the Australian public. By its very nature, when you have reform there is a lot of complexity to it. There is a lot to understand and comprehend. We did that with other reform programs over the last 9½ years. We did it with the GST. At the time, the Australian public got to understand exactly what we were doing. We are doing it again now.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the state of the House.
(Hon. IR Causley)—I have ruled before when we have successive motions that I think it is disrupting the House. I will not accept the motion.

—Thank you for your ruling on that, Mr Deputy Speaker. Any discussion on this MPI, which is about Australian families and their social wellbeing and the investment in skilling the Australian work force, must also take place in the context of looking at what has happened in the past. I have already referred to the 1993 Keating reforms, which we are continuing. We must also look at the record and performance of the previous government. One of its former senior ministers is now the Leader of the Opposition. The record of the Leader of the Opposition during that time is an absolutely abysmal one.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the state of the House.

—I just ruled on that, Member for Shortland. I have ruled in the past that where we have successive calls for a quorum I believe it is disrupting the House. I took two and I am not going to take another.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I appreciate the ruling that you have made, but I cannot find, having looked at House of Representatives Practice, what underpins that particular ruling. I want to say that I accept you have a responsibility to ensure that the House is not disrupted—
—I am sure that if the Chief Opposition Whip has a close look at House of Representatives Practice he will see what I am relying on.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I apologise to you. I will take up your instruction. I did peruse House of Representatives Practice on another occasion but I will do so again. If I am permitted I might be able to take the matter up privately outside the chamber.

—Those points of order and interruptions remind me of one of my favourite black and white movies with Jimmy Stewart, Mr Smith Goes to Washington, because of all the filibustering that has taken place in order to take up my time. Those opposite do not like the Leader of the Opposition’s record being exposed in this chamber. We know that this MPI is a fraud. It is a fraud because it certainly exposes what the ALP in government failed to achieve. During the time that Mr Beazley was the minister for employment and education—basically he was the minister for jobs and skills, which is part of what this MPI is all about—we had one million unemployed, 329,000 long-term unemployed and teenage unemployment of 34.5 per cent. How did Mr Beazley feel about being minister for jobs and skills? This is what he said:

quote.para: ... I lost a lot of ambition and I stopped straining ... I thought that there was less capacity to achieve in that portfolio than just about any I have had.

speech.para: That is what the Leader of the Opposition said. That was quoted in the biography on Mr Beazley by Peter Fitzsimmons. The opposition’s record is an abysmal one and yet we have a government right now that is trying to introduce workplace relations reforms which will help further to improve employment prospects for Australians. One only has to go to today’s Daily Telegraph to see some examples of long-term unemployed young Australians who are talking about coming up with agreements for working on weekends without penalties. Fred Whitbread is quoted as saying:

quote.para: I wouldn’t mind as long as it is benefiting my long-term career.

speech.para: Following that, another guy, Adel Yahko, said:

quote.para: I’ll work seven days a week, it doesn’t matter.

speech.para: What they understand is that the way to advance from job to job is actually to be in a job to begin with. The people in the opposition do not understand that. They have never worked in the area of recruitment. They have no understanding. They have never run small business.

talk.start.para: Mr Albanese interjecting—

—The member for Grayndler can hardly make any contribution to the MPI; he failed to talk about the MPI. We all know that the best way to advance yourself is to be already in a job. These young people understand that. They need employment. Workplace relations reforms will provide that opportunity. The Leader of the Opposition cannot bring himself to use the word ‘rollback’ any more but that is exactly—(Time expired)
—Order! The discussion is now concluded.

talker.name: Ley, Sussan, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary (Children and Youth Affairs)
talker.name: Ms LEY

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Monday, 31 October, 2005, at 12.30 pm, unless the Speaker or, in the event of the Speaker being unavailable, the Deputy Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour for the meeting.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak briefly to the motion and then move an amendment. You would be aware that the sitting week which was scheduled to occur last week was cancelled on the motion of the government. It was a matter that was determined by the Leader of the House and the Prime Minister—the Prime Minister then writing to the Speaker about the matter. We think it is an act of contempt towards this parliament for this government to think that sitting dates are its plaything.

speech.para: The parliamentary secretary at the table is expressing some amazement at this. She might be amazed to learn that we have asked parliamentary chamber research staff about this and they are unable to identify a time that that has happened since this parliament was created at Federation. What that means is that this is the most arrogant government we have had since Federation. This is a government that is more contemptuous of this parliament and what it represents than any government we have had in the time since Australia has been a nation. It is a disgrace. We understand that in times of national emergency there might be a need to recall the parliament early, but there is no excuse for cancelling scheduled sitting dates. The amendment I will now move will achieve the result. I move that all words after ‘fixes’ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words—

talker.name: Ley, Sussan, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary (Children and Youth Affairs)
talker.name: Ms LEY

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the question be now put.

speech.para: Question put.

talk.start.para: —Look at this!
—Order!

—Mr Speaker, you called that the doors should be locked and they were left opened. That is a defiance of your ruling. The member for Goldstein came in after you said the doors should be locked and they were held open to accommodate his entry.
—I hear what the Chief Opposition Whip is saying. I did not see this.
—Mr Speaker, further to the intervention of the member for Chifley, he swapped seats with the member for Prospect in order to make that intervention—

—Mr Speaker, I put it to you that the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education just acknowledged that the member for Goldstein was out of order. There is precedence in this House for someone in the same situation—I think it was the member for Lindsay—to be excluded and having to stand in the middle. The member for Goldstein was not present in the chamber when the division was called.
—I have already ruled on that matter. I did not see the incident.
—That is not a ruling. I put it to you that you ask—
—I asked for the doors to be locked. The doors have been locked.
—You can’t push an attendant out of the way to get into the chamber.
—Mr Speaker—
—The member for Denison cannot take a point of order when he is out of his seat.
—Ask him.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The last time this happened there were two members. There was the member for Lindsay and Mrs Danna Vale—I do not recall the name of her seat, I am sorry.
—Hughes. They were asked by the Speaker to tell the truth about the circumstances, and they did so. Would you ask the member for Goldstein to tell the truth about the circumstances?
—I will ask the member for Goldstein whether he entered the chamber after the door was locked. Remain in your seat, Member for Goldstein.
—Mr Speaker, I entered through an open door.
—Mr Speaker, on a further point of order. The member for Goldstein’s answer might be all very humorous—
—Order! I can’t hear the Manager of Opposition Business. Members on my right!

—but the point he needs to truthfully answer is whether he entered through the door after you had called for the doors to be locked. That is the thing he needs to truthfully answer, and he has not done so. If he misleads this House, that has penalties.
—With due respect to the Manager of Opposition Business, I am not sure that is a reasonable question. The question was: did he enter while the door was open? The door clearly was open.

debate.para: An opposition member—He came through a closed door.

talk.start.para: —Does the member for Denison have something further to add?

—Yes, Mr Speaker. My point of order is this: the prior practice of the House in an instance that this emerged previously—when a member entered the House past the attendant who was closing the doors the member was required not to participate in the division.
—That is not true.
—Order! The member for Denison has the call.

—That is the circumstance that applied in this instance. If the question is asked of the member whether he entered after your order that the doors be locked was put, he would be obliged to answer truthfully that that was the case and should not participate in the division.
—I have ruled on this matter, and the ruling stands.
—Gary Hardgrave gave him up.
—Mr Speaker, I accept the fact that you have made a ruling. Could I request that you examine the tapes of the procedure and report back if necessary?
—Order! Members on my right! I thank the Chief Opposition Whip, and I will endeavour to look at this matter. If there is any record I will look at it accordingly.
—Order! It being after 4.30 pm, I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I require that the question be put immediately without debate.

subdebate.1.para: Bill returned from Main Committee without amendment; certified copy of the bill presented.
Ordered that this bill be considered immediately.
Bill agreed to.

motionnospeech.name: Mrs DRAPER
motionnospeech.inline: —I present the report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are being placed on the table.

motionnospeech.name: Ms LEY
motionnospeech.inline: —I present documents on the following subjects, being petitions which are not in accordance with the standing and sessional orders of the House:

quote.para: Relating to the Codex Agreement—from the member for McPherson—520 Petitioners
Relating to tax payer funded advertising—from the member for Page—41 Petitioners
Relating to use of the Millennium Development Goals and the ‘Make Poverty History’ campaign—from the member for Gellibrand—42 Petitioners

Relating to the proposed industrial relations changes—from the member for Brand—159,616 Petitioners

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —There is no greater symbol of the Howard government’s contempt for our heritage than its request for roadworks at Anzac Cove. In 2003, the Prime Minister promised to protect Anzac Cove. He promised to make Anzac Cove the first listing on the new National Heritage List. On 18 December 2003, the Prime Minister said:

quote.para: It seems to me ... entirely appropriate that the Anzac site at Gallipoli should represent the first nomination for inclusion on the National Heritage List. And, although it’s not on Australian territory, anyone who has visited the place will know that once you go there you feel it as Australian as the piece of land on which your home is built.

speech.para: Instead of protecting Anzac Cove, this government and this Prime Minister requested roadworks which have damaged the site forever. The Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee inquiry into matters relating to the Gallipoli Peninsula, which reported today, have confirmed this. The inquiry found:

quote.para: ... that significant sites of the ANZAC campaign ... have been lost forever. The coastal road has been widened beyond the extent necessary to ensure visitors’ safety; spoil has been deliberately dumped onto the beach below; there were no environmental measures put in place to minimise erosion from the construction ...

speech.para: The inquiry also found:

quote.para: ... Australian authorities and the Australian government were complacent in their response to allegations and evidence that this damage was occurring.

speech.para: The Howard government’s complacency continues to this day. In their minority report, government senators state:

quote.para: ... the Australian Government has, at all times, acted appropriately and correctly.

speech.para: How exactly is the trashing of this sacred site to all Australians acting appropriately and correctly? It is an extraordinary statement given the government, firstly, requested the road works and, then, failed to properly monitor the project. This complacency now threatens other elements of our Anzac heritage. Further roadwork upgrades are planned for Anzac Cove, but the government has already dismissed calls by the Senate inquiry for:

quote.para: ... remedial action before the onset of winter to stabilise and restore the vegetation at ANZAC Cove.

speech.para: To some extent the damage is done. What Australians saw for 90 years when they went to that site was that the integrity of the site remained largely the same as it was in 1915. When you went there you could get that sense of experience. Diggers who went back there certainly have said that that is the case, as have historians such as Les Carlyon, as have archaeologists and as have the RSL.

The government must ensure that it does not get worse. It must ensure that this remedial action is undertaken before the onset of winter to ameliorate the scarring caused by the roadworks and to minimise future erosion. Proper heritage management plans must be put in place in partnership with the government of Turkey. Clear guidelines must be put in place for the future management, recovery, reburial or storage of human remains at Gallipoli which were uncovered by these roadworks. The Howard government must end its complacency on this issue and it must learn from its mistakes. It must ensure that no further damage is done to one of our most sacred sites.

Mr Speaker, you may well recall that when I first raised this issue of the degradation of this site in the parliament the Prime Minister’s response was to say arrogantly that it is regrettable that the question was even asked. Thank goodness the opposition did raise it or it could have been even worse. But now is the time for complacency to end. It should take on board the Senate inquiry recommendations and ensure that no further damage is done. It should get serious about protecting Australia’s heritage.

talk.start.para: —I rise to pay tribute to Francis Eugene Joseph Galbally. Frank died yesterday after a long illness. He would have been 83 today. Over the course of one’s life, you come across many people whom you respect and admire. There are few who achieved distinction in so many diverse fields as Frank Galbally. Francis was a brilliant advocate, an author, a great contributor to Australia’s public policy, a defender of democracy against dictatorship in Greece, a proud husband and father, a man of intellect, of compassion and a man of passion. And he made the world’s finest vodka martini.

speech.para: Francis Galbally came from a family of Irish Catholic provenance. He considered becoming a priest; indeed, he attended the seminary at Werribee for three years before joining the Navy after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. On his return from the war, he studied law at the University of Melbourne and began his career as a solicitor. He never went to the bar, and always told me that he had made a very wise decision.

I will not say too much about his legal accomplishments because his legal colleagues are better able to do that. I will just say that the tributes to him are replete with references to his being the world’s most successful defence advocate—a man who took on causes that were unpopular and even dangerous. He was, as former Victorian Chief Justice John Phillips described him, ‘a very brave, lion-hearted man’. The fact is that the demands of the defence took their toll. He once told me that, despite his incredible run of successes, he did not want to do any more murder trials because taking the responsibility for somebody else’s life was overwhelming.

I first met Frank in 1975 and our relationship developed over the course of his work on the report on post-arrival programs and services. We then worked together on the Ethnic Television Review Panel and the Implementation Team for Multicultural Television and he was my chairman at the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. Frank was a wise, generous and dear friend. He became involved with ethnic issues because, when Malcolm Fraser asked him what he wanted to do when we won government in 1975, Frank said he was concerned about the situation of Australia’s ethnic communities.

Malcolm Fraser, sharing these concerns, made him Chairman of the Committee on Post-Arrival Programs and Services. The resulting report, which had all its recommendations accepted and funded, was a watershed in multicultural philosophy and practice. Its fundamental principles were: equal opportunity and equality of access to general services, the provision of special services where these are needed, respect for cultural diversity, consultation, self-help and self-reliance.

The Galbally report, as it became known, institutionalised the commitment to multiculturalism: the right of all Australians to express and share their cultural heritages, the right to equality of treatment and the removal of discriminatory barriers—rights which were always accompanied, in Frank’s mind, by the obligation to make a fundamental commitment to Australia. The Fraser government’s implementation of these principles would, in itself, have earned Frank a place in Australia’s history, but he went on to establish multicultural television, which had stalled, and to oversee the translation of the vision of a multicultural television service into reality. That reality is with us today, and for the service to have survived despite repeated onslaughts from both left and right is a tribute to how well Frank built it.

I believe that the work of Frank Galbally contributed significantly to the fact that what emerged from the mass immigration of the last half century was an admirable, decent, harmonious multicultural Australia—a society based on the appreciation of cultural diversity and on tolerance and mutual respect. Frank Galbally was a distinguished Australian who made a very distinguished contribution. He was a man of vision who conceived things that people had not thought of before and he had the capacity and toughness to translate them into reality. He will be sorely missed, and the thoughts of many people will be with his wife, Bernadette, and his many children, Michael, David, Francis, Simon, Paul, Bernard, Elsa and Joe.

talk.start.para: —When the Australian people pay their taxes they expect the money to be spent on services for the Australian people. Nobody likes paying tax, but when they do they at least know it is going to a good cause. But we now have a government which is wasteful and slothful with taxpayers’ money. This is the highest taxing Australian government in history—a government which is spending $100 million, not of its money but of taxpayers’ money, on advocating a policy which has not yet even been introduced into this parliament. It is a government that is buying advertisements on prime time television which appear every five minutes at $90,000 a pop. It is a complete waste of taxpayers’ money that this government should be ashamed of.

speech.para: Today we heard in the House the revelation that the government had produced 60,000 pamphlets on the industrial relations changes only to have them pulped because they were not good enough. This is a government which claims to be a good economic manager but is prepared to see taxpayers’ money wasted and thrown around like confetti at a wedding. And that is not all. There has been other wasteful spending from the government in the last 12 months. We have seen $100 million spent so far on private recruitment agencies. I do not deny that some use of private recruitment agencies is appropriate, but spending $100 million on private agencies for government recruitment shows that this government has an extreme ideological approach to these matters. I would contend that this sort of recruitment could be done much more efficiently by members of the Australian Public Service. This government has an ideological obsession with outsourcing.

Last year an estimated $10 million was spent on media monitoring by this government—$10 million to watch themselves on television and read about themselves in newspapers. What an outrageous waste of money which would not pass the reasonableness test of the average Australian taxpayer. Another $80,000 was spent on massages for selected public servants. I do not deny that those public servants work very hard, but I think the average taxpayer would say that $80,000 on massages for selected public servants is not a good use of taxpayers’ money—and if it is good enough for some public servants then it is good enough for all.

The arrogance goes further. A few months ago I put a question on notice to the Minister for Human Services asking him if he had sought legal advice about his powers in relation to the Minister for Family and Community Services. I asked him if he had paid, at taxpayer expense, for legal advice on whether he was more powerful than the Minister for Family and Community Services. For good measure I asked the Minister for Family and Community Services whether she had sought legal advice about the Minister for Human Services. To her credit, the Minister for Family and Community Services answered promptly and said no. The Minister for Human Services took months to respond. Last week I received an answer or, rather, a non-answer: ‘My department seeks legal advice on a range of matters from time to time.’ That was his answer. He refused to indicate how much he spent on legal advice about how much power he has in relation to a so-called colleague.

It is an arrogant contempt of the processes of this parliament when a minister says, ‘I refuse to answer a question from an elected member of parliament.’ I have written again to the Minister for Human Services and asked the same question under the Freedom of Information Act, and I expect to receive an answer. Then we will know how much money he spent finding out how powerful he is in relation to the Minister for Family and Community Services.

We see an arrogant contempt for the forms of this House and an arrogant contempt in the use of taxpayers’ hard-earned money—taxpayers who work long hours going about their business and paying their tax. Nobody likes paying tax, but they do it because they know that community services will benefit. But taxpayers can receive no comfort from the way this government spends its money because it spends it on such things as advertisements and pulped pamphlets.

talk.start.para: —It being 5 pm, the debate is interrupted. Before calling the adjournment, I point out to the member for Prospect that he went very close to committing a contempt himself. If he wants to talk about an individual member of this chamber, he should do so by substantive motion.

debate.para: M r A ndrews to present a bill for an act to amend the law relating to workplace relations, and for related purposes. (Workplace Relations Amendment (Work Choices) Bill 2005)
M r R uddock to present a bill for an act to amend the law relating to terrorist acts, and for other purposes. (Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005)

item.para: acknowledges that the Federal Government formally recognised Australian South Sea Islanders as a distinct cultural group in 1994 and that this was followed by the Queensland Government in 2000;
Recognises that Australian South Sea Islanders, as a group, experience disadvantage compared to the general Australian population;

notes with disappointment that many of the practical measures to overcome this disadvantage recommended by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in its report The Call for Recognition: A Report on the Situation of Australian South Sea Islanders have not been implemented despite their endorsement by the Federal Government in 1994; and

calls on the Federal Government to go beyond the symbolism of formal recognition of Australian South Sea Islanders by expanding current policies and enacting appropriate measures designed to deliver real assistance to this group.

debate.para: M r B aird to move:

item.para: notes with concern the:

item.label: (a)
item.para: ongoing human rights abuses in Zimbabwe;

item.label: (b)
item.para: lack of accountable government and the failure to hold free and fair elections;

item.label: (c)
item.para: ongoing suppression of opposition political parties and human rights activists; and

item.label: (d)
item.para: implementation of Operation Murambatsvina (Clean Out the Trash) which has led to the internal displacement and famine; and
calls on the Zimbabwean Government to:

item.label: (a)
item.para: uphold the rule of law;

item.label: (b)
item.para: ensure that its citizens human rights are respected;

item.label: (c)
item.para: establish conditions and provide the means for citizens who have been internally displaced under Operation Murambatsvina to return voluntarily and with dignity to their homes or places of residence or resettle voluntarily in another part of the country; and

item.label: (d)
item.para: respect the rights of victims of Operation Murambatsvina, including access to justice and appropriate reparations, including restitution, rehabilitation and compensation.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley) took the chair at 9.30 am.

talk.start.para: —We have been talking a lot recently about moving people from welfare to work. I want to draw your attention to a couple of constituents of mine who, in their time of greatest need, have been let down by the government. Dr Peter Todd from Newtown is a psychologist in private practice. In August he suffered a heart attack and needed a triple bypass. There were many complications from the surgery. He is now in a wheelchair, and his doctors have told him it will take three to six months to recover. He was in his own practice and had no income protection or paid sick leave, so on 6 September he lodged a claim for sickness benefit. He had $6,000 in a bank account to pay the costs of re-establishing himself in private practice when he recovered. Centrelink, of course, refused to pay him sickness benefit until he ran down his money. The rules were applied rigidly to his case and no discretion was exercised.

speech.para: Dr Todd has been a valuable member of his community for over 40 years, working with disadvantaged and marginalised people, particularly with HIV-AIDS patients at the Albion Street clinic, and yet, at the only time in decades that he has needed any help or support, he has been turned away. He felt as if Centrelink had pulled the rug out from under him. He told my office:

quote.para: It is making it very hard for me to return to private practice. I will have a tax debt unpaid with no option to pay it and no money to re-establish my practice.

speech.para: The stress of the ordeal has greatly affected his health, and he has felt in his time of need that he was treated harshly and unsympathetically by the system.

Another constituent of mine—let us call him Frank—from Waterloo was addicted to heroin and methadone for decades and received DSP for 13 years. He has turned his life around, and in 2003 he stopped using drugs and became a bike courier. In May he became ill due to a nasty ear infection and needed income support for six weeks. He made his claim, and it was eventually accepted by Centrelink, but he did not receive a cent until the day before he returned to work. He was treated with such suspicion that he was forced, over and over again, to lodge numerous documents. Of course, it was extremely stressful for him not to be in receipt of any income during his time of illness. He ended up behind in his rent and had to borrow money for food. Someone who is marginally employed in this way and has a history of illness is very close at any time to becoming homeless or suffering ongoing health effects, and the treatment that Centrelink gave to this man was, I believe, unnecessarily sceptical and unnecessarily harsh.

Both of these hardworking Australians, when they needed short-term support through their illnesses, were offered no empathy, no understanding and no support, only a very suspicious attitude and an obsession with form filling, paperwork and reviews. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am concerned that Australia might be about to miss an important opportunity to move its television services to an all-digital environment. Currently, digital programs and analog programs are simulcast across Australia. The government had indicated that by 2008 the analog network would be switched off. There now seems to be a move to defer that to 2012. I am opposed to that. If we are going to be a modern, progressive country, we need to move to the all-digital environment now. I understand that there has not been a great take-up of digital technology in the community, but the way out of that is that set-top boxes now only cost about $60. It may well be in the government’s interest and in the networks’ interest to provide all remaining receivers who do not have a digital service with a set-top box so that the analog system can be switched off on time in 2008. The benefit of doing that, of course, is that it removes this wasteful dual transmission service and frees up the spectrum that is currently being used by the analog service. It also then allows the networks to put the money saved from running two services in parallel right across Australia, using hundreds of transmitters, into further Australian production.

speech.para: While I am talking about Australian production, I am angry with the ABC. I now find out that they produce only 20 hours of first-run drama a year. That is disgraceful, and that has to be fixed. I also now find out that they are not subject to the same Australian content rules as the commercial networks. How could that be? When we set up the ABC charter, did we just expect the ABC to do the right thing by Australians? That was probably the case, but I think the government should now move to insert in the ABC’s charter a requirement that they match the same Australian content rules as those that apply to the commercial stations. I think that is fair. In fact, many of us would expect that they do better than the commercial stations. It is incumbent on the ABC board to listen to what I am saying and to listen to the expectation of all Australians so that our ABC can in fact be our ABC.

talk.start.para: —There are many aspects of the government’s radical industrial relations plan which I find repugnant and un-Australian. I want to refer to just one of those now. It is the example given in the government’s own publication and propaganda paid for by taxpayers about Billy, the unemployed person whose is offered a job ‘contingent on him accepting an AWA’. Note that: contingent on him accepting an AWA—that is, he takes the job only if he accepts the boss’s terms of an AWA individual contract that, presumably, as an unemployed person he is supposed to be able to bargain on some equal footing. No Australian believes that. It is interesting that for years the government have said that people would not be offered a job on a take it or leave it basis with AWAs. Now, not only do they admit it; they have put it in their taxpayer funded propaganda. The propaganda goes on to say this:

quote.para: The AWA Billy is offered explicitly removes award conditions for public holidays, rest breaks, bonuses, annual leave loadings, allowances, penalty rates and shift/overtime loadings.

speech.para: That means that Billy is not entitled to any of those public holidays—none of them. He can work on Anzac Day and on Christmas Day and get the same hourly rate as if he was working on a Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday from nine to five. He has no right to annual leave loadings and he has no right to shift loadings. So he can work the midnight shift and not get one cent more. This is what the government proposes to do to Billy—to take advantage of the most vulnerable, to kick the most vulnerable people when they are down.

One of the things that struck me when I first heard this was my response not as a politician or as someone who was committed to the labour movement and the rights of working Australians but as a parent. What this government is proposing to do is to say to Billy’s mum and dad: ‘You will be the first generation since white settlement in Australia to bequeath to your children worse conditions than you had when you were their age. You will bequeath to your children fewer rights in the workplace than you enjoyed when you commenced work 20 or 30 years ago.’ That is in fact what Billy’s parents are being asked to sign up to by this government.

That was the response I had, not as a politician, not as a committed Labor person, not as someone concerned for working Australians, but as a father of four children. I am not prepared in any of those capacities to stand by and see this happen. It is clear from the reaction already from the public, some of which we know from our electorates and some of which we know from the published opinion polls, that Australians understand that too. It is fundamentally wrong; it is un-Australian. At a time when we talk about mateship and camaraderie, and at Anzac Day services where we talk about looking after the less well off in our society, to say to the most vulnerable people in our community, ‘You should be placed on conditions that are not only worse than every other worker has at that time but worse than the conditions that your parents had when they were at work,’ is something parents will not tolerate. I look forward to the debate on this when the parliament resumes in a couple of weeks time. But more than that: I look forward to the debate on it in the community in the next two years.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: —I want to take this opportunity to praise the work of two school communities within Bass Coast Shire within the electorate of Flinders. In particular, on 21 November the rebuilt and brand new buildings at Cowes Primary School will be opened. This follows a tragic fire some time ago, and the school community has responded magnificently. Led by the principal, Ms Sue Becker, the school community, the staff, the council, the parents, the friends, the families and, in particular, the students have worked not only to recover that which was lost but to create a better, stronger school than that which was there before. It is tremendous example of taking adversity and turning it into the opportunity to create something new.

speech.para: At the Commonwealth level we will have made a contribution of $600,000 to the reconstruction and re-establishment of buildings. I am delighted that we were able to do that. I thank the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Brendan Nelson, who within 24 hours of the fire had made a public commitment to help in the reconstruction and rehabilitation of the school. It was a tremendous outcome and a great cooperative project between the school community and the Commonwealth. I also acknowledge the important work of the state. I congratulate all those involved in the reconstruction, redevelopment and rehabilitation of Cowes Primary. I think that 21 November should be a day of celebration.

The second thing I want to do is pay tribute to the school community of Bass Valley Primary. This is a school which serves small towns such as Coronet Bay, Corinella, Pioneer Bay, Grantville, Kernot, Glen Alvie and Glen Forbes—all of these small towns. Bass Valley Primary is a tremendous little school. I am delighted to be able to inform the House and the broader community in that area that we will have $50,000 for upgrading playgrounds, play equipment and the general facilities for schoolchildren under the Investing in Our Schools program. I know that the principal, Dale Hendrick, does a tremendous job, as do his staff and the school community who put together the application. They have worked incredibly hard. The work that they do is outstanding and I congratulate them on their achievements. I wish to pass on my thanks to all of them and say that it is a tremendous outcome which is fully deserved for a great school which does a great job.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on behalf of all family carers who are caring for their loved ones in my electorate of Richmond and throughout Australia. There are 2.5 million carers in Australia who look after family members or friends—people with disabilities, mental illness or chronic conditions, or the frail and aged. They look after them day in and day out, 365 days a year.

speech.para: The contribution that carers make is not only to the people that they care for but also to the community and the economy more broadly. It is estimated that carers save the Australian economy approximately $20 billion annually through unpaid work, yet their work unfortunately goes largely unrecognised. Family carers are always telling me that they are angry, tired and frustrated by the appalling lack of support that they receive from the federal government.

Last month I joined hundreds of carers and their families who had travelled to Canberra from every corner of Australia to beg the Howard government to ‘Walk a mile in my shoes’. To symbolise the lonely and exhausting journey of family carers, we placed hundreds of pairs of old, worn-out shoes on the lawns of Parliament House. Many of these I brought on behalf of carers living in my electorate of Richmond. Each pair of shoes was tagged with an individual, personal message written from a family carer to the Howard government, asking to give them more support.

Take a carer like Cindy Petersons from Bangalow, who cares for her daughter Alexandra. Alexandra is 13 years old and has cerebral palsy. Alexandra’s mum, Cindy, wants the Howard government to understand what it is like to care for someone every hour of the day, year after year, without support or respite. Another carer is Marie Dudgeon, also from Bangalow, who cares for her son Glen. Eight years ago Glen was in a car accident that left him brain damaged, blind and physically disabled. Glen’s care is indeed 24/7, 365 days a year, and takes a huge physical and emotional toll on Marie and her family. Marie wants the federal government to recognise her never-ending care for Glen and hear her cry for more help and support.

There are also carers like Geoff Jones and Steve Pollitt from Tweed Heads, who are members of the Tweed Heads Mental Health Carers Network. The network is a voluntary group coordinated by the tireless June Saville. It provides much needed support for families who care for loved ones with mental health issues and it advocates improving the lives of carers. The Tweed Heads Mental Health Carers Network has asked me to take their message to the Howard government, so I am calling on this government to stop making the lives of carers harder and to start listening to them. We need to give them greater recognition for the vital work that they do. We need to provide greater financial support that recognises the cost of caring and we need to provide greater support in the workplace so that carers can pursue their own careers and livelihoods. After nine long years, this government has done little to ease the burden on carers. Today I am calling on members of the Howard government to walk a mile in the shoes of the millions of carers around Australia who sacrifice everything to look after their family day in and day out. It is time that the government started taking their needs seriously and provided enough support for the carers.

talk.start.para: —This morning I would like to congratulate all those people involved in the Advancing Burleigh project, which was launched last year by me and the councillor for the area, Councillor Greg Betts. The Advancing Burleigh project resulted from a combination of the Gold Coast City Council’s identification of Burleigh as one of the 10 centres of the Pacific Innovation Corridor and, more recently, the council’s Centre Improvement Program.

speech.para: Through the Regional Partnerships program, we were able to provide some Commonwealth funding for the Advancing Burleigh project. The Gold Coast City also contributed to the project. The Burleigh Chamber of Commerce also contributed because the Burleigh business community understood and identified how important it was to get this project off the ground. We needed to be able to market Burleigh, put Burleigh on the map and give those small businesses the opportunity of growing their businesses, growing the economic demands of the area and providing jobs for the area. Through the Regional Partnerships program, that is what we are trying to achieve.

The Burleigh project aimed to progress the Burleigh region, as I said, by marketing and building on the economic growth of the area, by creating new jobs and by revitalising the town centre. I have often said that Burleigh is the secret treasure of the Gold Coast. It is a bit of a sleepy village, but it is a very popular holiday destination. There are a lot of small businesses and, by giving them a kick-start with this marketing project, we were able to put them on the map, so to speak.

The project has been extremely successful. It has been run over the last 12 months. We were able to engage consultant Jo Eady to push the project along. It is through her determination to see this succeed that we have got to where we are today. Jon Ingall, who is the president of the Burleigh Chamber of Commerce, certainly got on board, and Michael Hart, who is the vice-president, drove the Burleigh Business Week by bringing all those businesses together. We had a mini expo during the week, and it culminated in a night of awards. We had eight awards during that night. We had around 80 businesses represented at that dinner and were able to recognise the expertise of a lot of the businesses in Burleigh.

We also launched advanceburleigh.com. This is a web site we have developed to put Burleigh on the map both nationally and internationally. Anyone visiting the area will be able to access advanceburleigh.com, see what is available there and hook into what I believe is a beautiful part of Gold Coast City. On behalf of all the people involved, I think we have come a long way in 12 months. We have advanceburleigh.com, we have brought in the Burleigh Business Awards, we have had the Burleigh Business Week and we have re-energised the Burleigh Chamber of Commerce. Congratulations to all of those involved.

talk.start.para: —A couple of wire service things jumped up at me today. Seeing as today is World Sight Day, it was great to see that the number of blind people worldwide has started to dwindle for the first time ever. The numbers have dropped from 45 million in the year 2000 to 38 million, despite the huge growth in the world population. But we are still talking about huge numbers.

speech.para: The other wire service announcement that related to this is that at the end of last month in my state of Tasmania 7,040 Tasmanians were waiting for elective surgery at public hospitals. It really worries me that we have six state and two territory Labor governments that seem to have a fixation with infrastructure—toll roads, buildings, bridges and the like. There seems to be, despite the huge amount of money they are getting from the GST revenue, little being spent on social infrastructure.

At the Royal Hobart Hospital, the state’s main teaching hospital, the waiting list grew from 3,334 at the end of June to 3,532 at the end of September. At the end of September 10,856 people were waiting for dental treatment in Tasmania. I think this is absolutely appalling.

Professor Taylor, who spoke about the World Health Organisation report into blindness, estimated that there were 50,000 Australians suffering from blindness and half a million Australians with visual impairment. Up to three-quarters of their eye problems were caused by conditions which were either preventable or treatable. That is worth repeating: three-quarters of the eye impairments suffered by these Australians are caused by conditions that are either preventable or treatable. He said that 40,000 Australians were on public hospital waiting lists for cataract surgery, some having to suffer for years before being operated on. I find it absolutely appalling that most of the 40,000 Australians on the waiting lists are being denied basic human rights. As Professor Taylor said, the community cannot afford to have people waiting too long for cataract surgery:

quote.para: The cost ... of the increased falls and fractures and demand on community service is enormous and cataract surgery is so cost effective.

speech.para: I would challenge all the state and territory Labor governments to really have a look at this issue today, World Sight Day. I think they are denying their citizens right across Australia basic human rights, and that needs to be rectified straightaway.

talk.start.para: —I rise in the chamber this morning to praise the contribution by this nation to the South Asia earthquake relief funds. We all know that there was recently a very large earthquake affecting areas of Pakistan, India and Afghanistan. It is to our credit as a nation that we were one of the first countries to make a very substantial contribution.

speech.para: Honourable members would be aware of the important role that Pakistan plays in the war against terror and also of its incredibly important geographical position, bordered as it is by Afghanistan, Iran, India and China, and I think there is only a 15-kilometre corridor between Pakistan and Tajikistan. So it is vital that we recognise the importance of Pakistan as an ally. President Musharraf was here earlier this year and that was a very important visit. It is vital that we continue to recognise the very difficult and important role that Pakistan is playing.

More important than recognising the vital role of Pakistan in the war against terror is the need for us as a wealthy nation to continue to provide humanitarian assistance to the tens of thousands of people who have been left homeless and the tens of thousands of people who have been injured. I am disturbed to hear that at least some 30,000 people have been killed. Many families have lost children; many children have lost parents. The increase in our contribution so far to $10 million is a very important step forward.

I want to commend the Minister for Foreign Affairs for looking very closely at this important challenge confronting South Asia. It is vital that countries from around the world continue to provide assistance and that we continue to provide additional assistance if required. Australian assistance is often well targeted and given very early. At times, countries give assistance of a nature that might not necessarily be needed, but Australian assistance is always well targeted. We are on the spot early. The increase in our assistance by a further $4.5 million, bringing it to $10 million, is really important. I hope that we continue to be generous and that we give more assistance if we find, on assessment, that more is required.

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister gave a very unsatisfactory response to a question I asked him during question time on Tuesday about his extreme industrial relations agenda. Inter alia, the Prime Minister refuses to guarantee that no employee will be worse off under his proposed extreme industrial relations agenda. I want to pay tribute to my senior researcher and media adviser, Adrian Leopardi, who is a very alert electorate officer for picking up what the Prime Minister said to Kerry O’Brien on Monday evening on The 7.30 Report. In part of the interview, Mr Howard said:

quote.para: We’ve had an ongoing debate in this country about a skills shortage. Why don’t a lot of young people go into apprenticeships? The reason is that they can get highly paid unskilled jobs as soon as they leave school.

speech.para: The Prime Minister’s own words are clear. In his view there are a lot of young people who are unskilled and who are being highly paid. What better proof than the Prime Minister’s own words that the most vulnerable members of the work force will be worse off under the Prime Minister’s extreme industrial relations agenda? What are these highly paid, unskilled jobs that the Prime Minister is referring to? It is obvious from his own words that people are going to be worse off when this legislation is passed by the Senate, as it surely will be. The Prime Minister has consistently dodged this issue and not told the truth to the people of Australia. Workers will be worse off.

In summary, these changes will hurt employees because they will allow employers to put workers onto individual contracts that cut take-home pay and reduce employment conditions to only five minimum standards. Workers who refuse to sign may be sacked without remedy. The changes will put downward pressure on the minimum wage. They will abolish protection from unfair dismissal for almost four million workers employed in companies with fewer than 100 staff.

Many people are contacting my office daily about the government’s proposed agenda. It was disgraceful to see yesterday in all the national papers the four-page advertisements about the industrial relations changes, advertisements costing millions of dollars of taxpayers’ money. The government is stripping employees of their rights, which will only hurt local families. That is why, while I am in this parliament, I will continue to fight against these extreme measures about to be visited on the decent, hardworking families of Australia.

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary (Foreign Affairs) and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs)
talker.name: Mr BILLSON

talk.start.para: —Today I raise two issues of particular concern to the Dunkley community. The first relates to the Banksia Centre, an outstanding and nationally recognised provider of respite care services operated under the auspices of the Brotherhood of St Lawrence. For some time now there has been particular community anxiety and concern about the future of that service, as its current location appears to be earmarked for sale by the Brotherhood of St Lawrence.

speech.para: In recognition of the outstanding work of the Banksia Centre and its staff, and in support of its carers and of the people who greatly believe in the work of the team at Banksia, the Howard government committed a timely and generous amount of $400,000 to support the relocation and redevelopment of the Banksia service. Some 18 months after I was assured that it would be just weeks before a firm and clear proposal was approved by the Brotherhood of St Lawrence for the relocation and redevelopment of the Banksia Centre, there is still no plan. There is no plan to accommodate this outstanding service, despite the grant being awarded, despite the public assurances, despite the great support of carers and staff.

There is now great alarm in the community. There is still no firm plan to implement the Brotherhood’s undertakings. I call on the Brotherhood of St Lawrence to implement those undertakings and give effect to those assurances, because the carers of people with dementia rely on the Banksia Centre and its respite care programs, both in-facility and host-home, and its other support services. The many families who would love to be able to make use of those services are looking for concrete, firm and urgent action by the Brotherhood to put in place real plans to make sure that the service’s future is secure and that its facilities are expanded and redeveloped, as has been the goal supported by the Howard government’s funding grant.

A second issue I raise in the time available to me relates to the very sad, dark and probably the most evil case of electoral misrepresentation I can recall—and that is the Bracks government’s ‘no tolls’ commitment to the people of my community in the east and south-east of Melbourne. Now that we have learnt that the project is not going ahead without tolls, the Howard government’s $540 million commitment will not be taken up, because the agreement signed by the Victorian government is not being implemented by the Victorian government.

The project is going ahead as a tollway. It will add considerable traffic volumes to an already congested intersection in the city that I represent. The Frankston freeway ends and crosses Cranbourne Road. It is one of the state’s busiest intersections right now and it will be made more so with the completion of EastLink. Traffic volumes are expected to rise by 23 per cent, or three times the normal projected growth. We need some support to alleviate the consequences of that impact on our local community, and an opportunity to get behind the regional effort to see the Frankston bypass and the Rutherford Road on-ramp put on the radar screen. I urge government at the state, local and federal levels to get behind those projects. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)—Order! In accordance with standing order 193 the time for members’ statements has concluded.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 14 September, on motion by Mr Pyne:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The government has conceded that the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2005 is aimed at correcting an anomaly resulting from the Australia-America free trade agreement. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing described the bill as correcting ‘an unintended drafting error’. However, this is an error that has added considerable compliance costs and undue delay in applications to have products approved. In the same contribution, the parliamentary secretary commented:

quote.para: The amendments seek to rectify an unintended consequence of previous amendments which came into force from 1 January 2005 to introduce into the marketing approval process certification requirements in relation to patents.

speech.para: The purpose of the bill is to restrict current patent certification requirements under section 26B(1) of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 for registering or listing therapeutic goods in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, ARTG.

The amendments are a response to major concerns raised by representatives from the complementary medicine and over-the-counter medicine sectors and the Australian biotechnology field that current requirements are too cumbersome, leading to unnecessary compliance costs. Thus the bill amends the act so that patent certification will be required only of those applicants who are required to submit safety or efficacy data when making their applications or, alternatively, who when making their application rely on data previously submitted to the TGA by another person or organisation in relation to an approved product. All other applicants may provide a notice to the Secretary of the Department of Health and Ageing that a section 26B(1) certificate is not required.

The amendments will remove the unnecessary requirement and burden imposed on applicants with products for which the patent certification requirement under the act is not relevant. The practical implication is that it will exempt the complementary and over-the-counter medicines industry from Australia-US Free Trade Agreement requirements which impose an obligation that products proposed to be listed on the register do not infringe existing patents, an obligation which generally involves conducting expensive, time-consuming global patent searches and research.

The background to this is that all therapeutic goods sold in Australia must be included on the ARTG. Therapeutic goods on the ARTG are regulated on a risk management approach. Higher risk therapeutic goods—that is, registered medicines—are subject to a high level of scrutiny, and the TGA must determine their quality, safety and efficacy. Lower risk therapeutic goods are ‘listed’. In that case, the TGA must determine their quality and safety but not their efficacy—that is, the TGA does not evaluate listed medicines prior to supply to determine whether they are effective.

In Australia, over 80 per cent of over-the-counter medicines do not require manufacturers to submit safety or efficacy data to the FTA. Therefore, they should not be required to obey strict patent certification requirements, as this act would have required. The bill will effectively alter the way these products are brought into the marketplace in this country by restricting patent certification requirements for products that do not require manufacturers to submit safety or efficacy data in their application.

The FTA draft encompassed a broader group of products in Australia than in the United States; thus, the current patent certification requirements are more onerous and cumbersome than they should be and more onerous and cumbersome than those of their competitors in the United States. In the US, complementary and over-the-counter medicines are treated as dietary supplements. Here they are treated as pharmaceuticals. Therefore, when the FTA was drafted and agreed to, it captured a far broader group of products in Australia than was captured in the United States. This puts Australia at a significant disadvantage in the light of the FTA provisions.

In the FTA, article 17.10(4) is directed at marketing approval processes for pharmaceutical products that ‘rely on evidence or information concerning the safety or efficacy of a product that was previously approved’. Most complementary and over-the-counter medicines are known as ‘listed goods’ as opposed to ‘registered goods’. However, reliance upon safety and efficacy data lodged by another party with the TGA is not required for listed goods. The bill aims to rectify this anomaly, because in the United States complementary and OTC medicines manufacturers do not have to comply with patent certification requirements in the marketing approval process. The amendments in this bill will also exempt the same industry players in this country from compliance.

The patent certification requirements in the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 went beyond the original intent of the FTA. This has been proven by the complementary and over-the-counter medicines industry inadvertently being caught in the stringent requirements thus imposed. The fact is that this oversight should not have occurred in the first place. The government was in such a rush to get the FTA and its ancillary documents through that it did not give much thought to the different regulatory regimes in the two countries or the unnecessary burden on the complementary health care industry here. Whilst we welcome the bill, we also say that the government should have acted immediately. Why did it take constant lobbying by the complementary and over-the-counter medicines sectors and the Australian biotech industry to pressure the government for change?

The Complementary Healthcare Council of Australia and the vitamins makers Blackmores have strongly lobbied the government since the FTA came into force on 1 January. They repeatedly stressed to the government the unnecessary and unreasonable costs of patent certification requirements. Figures of up to $80 million in compliance costs have been quoted. Each application, as I understand it, in research, in exploration and in investigation, costs a minimum of $5,000, which they were not obliged to meet previously and which was originally intended for mainstream drug companies.

Also highlighted to the government in this lobbying exercise was the additional burden on consumers, possibly a five to eight per cent increase in costs to consumers. Add to this the undue delay for these industry groups—and thereby the consumers, the users, the people needing it—in seeking to have their products listed on the register. The government should consider carefully the legislative purpose and intention of its instruments before rushing them through and then trying retrospectively to correct a situation which has hurt companies, hurt employees and hurt Australian consumers.

The Complementary Healthcare Council of Australia said that the patent law changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act had gone far beyond the original intent of the FTA and that complementary medicines have been caught up in onerous new requirements. The FTA and subsequent amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act put the Australian industry in a singularly unfair position compared to United States manufacturers and industry. Marcus Blackmore from Blackmores has stated: ‘We believe there is adequate evidence that the American dietary supplement industry does not have to comply, and that puts us at a significant disadvantage.’

The change that we are putting through the parliament today does represent a victory for the complementary health care industry, a victory for commonsense, a victory for analysis of legislation and a victory in a situation where this legislation should not have been rushed through in the first place. There can be an issue of concern, still, that potential exists for the United States to challenge legislation if they believe the amendments breach the FTA. They can do this under chapter 21 provisions.

The purpose of the act is to ensure quality, safety and efficacy of therapeutic goods. That is the fundamental requirement of this act. The parliamentary secretary has said in his second reading speech:

quote.para: While the amendment simplifies the administrative burden on industry, it in no way changes or diminishes industry’s responsibility in relation to supplying medicines that fully meet all the existing safety, quality and efficacy requirements as set out in the Therapeutic Goods Act.

speech.para: That is quite clear. Of course it in no way reduces the requirements, the oversight, the mandatory stipulations on industry. The question is whether for the past year, or most of it, this industry should have been essentially put at a disadvantage to US competitors and whether consumers should have had to bear this cost. It should never have occurred.

After consultation with key industry bodies—such as Medicines Australia and the Complementary Healthcare Council—affected by the FTA and the subsequent amendments to the act, these bodies are of the view that the bill corrects an oversight by the government. It removes burdens on their industry unnecessarily imposed in the first place. The current provisions are having a major impact on their industry, with many losing money, with higher costs for single applications and with undue delay in having products on the register. Throughout the field, they also totally agree that the original bill in response to the FTA, earlier this year, should not have been enacted in that fashion. It was an error made by the government which must be fixed. I join the government in recommending this bill for approval.

talk.start.para: —The purpose of the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2005 is to restrict the patent certification requirements under subsection 26B(1) of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. The amendments contained in this bill do not change any aspect of existing health, safety or quality controls for therapeutic goods under the act; they simply address the unintended breadth of an amendment relating to patents that came into force on 1 January this year. The Howard government acknowledges and supports the rights of consumers to make informed choices on matters of health. It also believes that people are entitled to expect that medicines available in Australia are both of high quality and safe when used appropriately.

speech.para: Whatever form medication takes, whether it be prescription drugs, over-the-counter remedies such as analgesics or cough mixture, or complementary medicines such as vitamins or homeopathy products, we want to be confident of the safety and quality of that medication. However, in our enthusiasm for ensuring safety and quality, we must be careful not to impose unnecessary bureaucracy or restrictions on manufacturers and suppliers of such goods. We need care and we need balance, because sometimes perfectly good legislation can, in practice, have unintended consequences, as is the case here.

In Australia, all therapeutic goods must be entered in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, the ARTG, before they can be supplied in or exported from Australia. The ARTG is the responsibility of the Therapeutic Goods Administration in the Commonwealth Department of Health and Ageing. To understand the meaning of this bill, we need to have a basic understanding of how therapeutic goods are assessed and either registered or listed in the ARTG. Within the registration process, there is a risk based system where the level of evaluation and regulatory control of a particular medicine is based on the relative risk of that product and on the seriousness of the condition for which it is intended to be used.

Medicines assessed as having a higher level of risk must be registered, as opposed to listed, in the ARTG. The degree of assessment and regulation these registered medicines undergo is rigorous and detailed, with sponsors required to provide comprehensive safety, quality and efficacy data. For example, prescription drugs are classed as high-risk registered medicines. They must be assessed and registered as such. However, while over-the-counter medicines such as analgesics and cough remedies must still be registered, they are evaluated under a low-risk classification.

Down the scale from the registered medicines under the act are listed medicines, which are usually considered to be relatively benign. The majority of the listed medicines are self-selected by consumers and used for self-treatment. Examples include vitamin and mineral supplements and products such as sunscreens. Listed medicines are assessed by the TGA for quality and safety but not efficacy. This does not mean that the products do not work; it simply means that the TGA has not evaluated them individually to see if they work. However, under the act, sponsors must hold information to substantiate all of their products’ claims and must make such evidence available to the TGA upon request. Sunscreens, for example, can be a listed product, but they must also have complied with testing under the Australian standard for sunscreens, and the company must be able to produce evidence of doing so.

This bill does not change any of the safeguards or quality controls currently contained in the act. It simply reduces the unintended scope of the patent amendments which came into force at the beginning of the year. The purpose of the earlier amendment was to prevent manufacturers of a generic version of a patented product from entering the market before the expiry of the patent covering that product. To this end, all applicants seeking to register or to list any product on the register are now required to provide section 26B(1) certificates declaring that they will not infringe a patent or, if they intend to enter the market before the expiry of any applicable patent, that they have notified the patent owner of their intention.

Unfortunately, the result of that earlier legislation is that all applicants for the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, not just those who want to market a generic product, are now required to have the section 26B(1) certificate. This can entail expensive global patent searches and legal advice. This bill responds to concerns raised by representatives from the complementary medicines industry, the over-the-counter medicines sector and the Australian biotechnology industry that the current patent certification requirements are onerous and broader than they need to be. This bill quite sensibly narrows the circumstances in which a patent certificate is required and restricts the requirement to those who under the act are required to submit safety and efficacy data and to those whose application relies on data previously submitted by another person in relation to an approved product.
