The practical effect of this amendment is that the majority of complementary medicine and over-the-counter products, such as sunscreens and throat lozenges, will no longer be subject to the current certification requirements because they are low-risk therapeutic goods and safety and efficacy data is not required under the act. This bill simply means that patent certification under the act will apply only to relevant applications. There will not be a blanket requirement under the act for all applications to register or to list therapeutic goods. I therefore commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2005. The Labor Party supports the bill because it enables the removal of obligations from parts of the industry which should not have had these obligations placed on them in the first place. The purpose of the bill is to amend the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 by creating an exemption to the current certification requirements for registering or listing therapeutic goods on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods.

speech.para: The amendments are in response to concerns raised by representatives of the complementary medicines industry, the over-the-counter medicines sector and the Australian biotechnology industry that the current patent certification requirements are more onerous and broad than they need to be. I know that all members of this House do not want that to be the case. We want to ensure that Australian people are able to obtain over-the-counter medicines and alternative medicines without the current onerous requirement. The bill proposes to exempt the complementary medicines industry and the over-the-counter medicines industry from the Australia-US Free Trade Agreement, which imposes an obligation on producers to prove that the products that they propose to list on the register do not infringe on existing patents. This generally involves expensive global patent searches.

The government has admitted that this bill is to correct an anomaly resulting from the Australia-US Free Trade Agreement. It has captured a sector that should not have been caught. I see that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing is at the table. I know that he has described this bill as being needed to address an unintended drafting error. We on this side of the House believe that that should be accommodated. We do not need to put in place requirements that are not needed.

The bill will effectively alter the way these products are brought into the market in Australia by restricting the patent certification requirements for particular products such as those that do not require manufacturers to submit safety or efficacy data in their application. The practical implication of this is that the majority of complementary and OTC products will no longer be subject to certification requirements. That is very laudable.

This error has added considerably to compliance costs and undue delay in applications to have products approved. That is the unintended nature of this drafting error. I know that the government would not want that to occur, and nor would we on this side of the House. We believe that you should streamline legislation so that you can get around these unintended errors that occur from time to time. Perhaps there should be more care taken in the drafting initially. This is an opportunity for us to see how there can be unintended consequences from the US free trade agreement. My contribution to this debate is only a small one. I join with the shadow minister in recommending that we support the legislation.

talker.name: Pyne, Chris, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing
talker.name: Mr PYNE

talk.start.para: —I thank particularly the member for Shortland for her short but very welcome contribution to the debate on the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2005. Of all the contributions, hers was probably the most erudite. She should give more speeches of that kind off the cuff. I would also like to thank the member for Fairfax, from the government side, and the member for Reid, the shadow minister, for their contributions to this debate.

speech.para: To sum up very briefly, the government became aware that there were some unintended consequences arising out of the signing of the free trade agreement with the United States that affected complementary medicine and over-the-counter medicine producers in Australia, applying a heavier burden on Australian manufacturers of these worthwhile products than on American producers of them. The government acted quickly to ensure that the same burden that falls on American producers falls on Australian producers.

This bill is very welcome in the complementary medicines sector and the over-the-counter sector. It will impact on about 80 per cent of over-the-counter medicines and 90 per cent of complementary medicines and will ensure that consumers have access to the full range of therapeutic products that they seek, without the unnecessary burden falling on business of having to find out about patents which would have little impact on their ability to market these products in Australia.

I welcome the contributions to the debate on this bill from the opposition and their support. I look forward to their continuing support on other issues of government policy in this area that will come up over the next 12 months.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 14 September, on motion by Mr Entsch:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005. The purpose of the bill, as we have heard previously, is to establish the mandatory energy efficiency opportunity assessments announced in the government’s energy white paper Securing Australia’s energy future in June 2004. It is the opposition’s intention to support the passage of this bill. However, I intend to move a second reading amendment to reflect that the bill does not address the urgent need for greater energy efficiency across all sectors of the economy, not just business.

speech.para: There is an urgent need for us, as a community, to address greater efficiency in energy use in our transport fuel, and this means a national focus on the long neglected policy area of urban public transport. We have unfortunately become a nation that drives, for example, 500 metres to the local shop instead of walking. We have cities that are uncomfortably congested, with huge costs to the economy now related to the issue of congestion. These situations obviously waste fuel and time, and they are a source of stress to people trying to carry out their daily lives with reasonable ease.

We have also unfortunately become a nation that all too often switches on the airconditioner the minute the lounge room seems to be a little hot in summer. We make the assumption that our energy supplies are infinite, but we can no longer take that for granted. We are also a nation that does not pay adequate attention to our own energy use in our workplaces and in our homes. Take Parliament House, for example: how many people walk out of their offices each Friday afternoon and leave the lights glaring all weekend? We, as a community, ought to be taking the lead in displaying to the Australian community that we are actually concerned about energy conservation in Australia.

I raise these issues because this is what the Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005 is about. It has the support of both sides of the House because it is about trying to focus in a practical way on how to improve our energy use in this community, with the initial focus on the business community. It is important that we consider these issues, because we cannot ignore the greenhouse implications of our energy use. We, as a community, have to get smarter about energy consumption in our homes and in our workplaces. These are vitally important policy issues relating to energy efficiency that are not addressed in this bill, and I intend to raise some of these issues this morning.

In addition, the bill does not take up the challenge of diversifying our energy supplies. Unfortunately, the government has been very muted in its support for alternative fuels and renewable energy technologies, yet these are an important part of our energy solutions. I contend that the government has also missed a wonderful opportunity to take up the bipartisan recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage report entitled Sustainable cities, many of which deal with energy efficiency initiatives that would make our cities move livable. It is interesting to note that the report says that, at a national level, at an Australian government level, we are going to try to work with our state and territory counterparts to get serious about improving public transport, especially in Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne. The opposition welcomes the government’s initiatives to address energy efficiency opportunities in the business sector, but I remind the House this morning that the opposition does not believe the bill goes far enough.

The bill requires large energy-using businesses to register with the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources. The end result being that they are required to submit a plan to undertake assessments of energy efficiency opportunities and report publicly on the outcomes of those assessments. This is about putting the finger on the business community in Australia to front up to their responsibilities on energy use. It is about public accountability and trying to build a new culture in our business community. Energy inefficiency is not a challenge to the Australian community alone but also a cost to those running businesses, which goes to their competitiveness both domestically and internationally, which therefore influences our capacity to create additional jobs in Australia.

I acknowledge that firms will be free to make decisions on investments identified via their normal business processes. It is not about Big Brother trying to direct on a daily basis how business operates in Australia but about trying to create a new culture of energy efficiency.

In Australia today, both the level of energy efficiency and the rate of improvement since 1973 are unfortunately lower than most other major industrialised countries. While the relatively lower price of energy in Australia may explain some of the difference, Australia has lower rates of energy efficiency improvements than countries with similar energy prices, such as Canada and the United States of America. More generally, experience in Australia and overseas has shown that there is often a gap between best practice energy efficiency and actual practice. While some technically feasible energy efficiency improvements will not be economically viable, there is also evidence that firms do not take up energy efficiency opportunities that are privately cost effective. This is clearly known as the energy efficiency gap, which is central to the bill.

The decision by government to introduce a mandatory assessment measure is aimed at addressing the gap. It comes in light of the fact that previous government programs have shown that a significant number of privately cost-effective energy efficiency improvements have been overlooked by the participating businesses.

Based on data from the ABS, around 250 companies are like to be covered by this measure. Those companies operate in a variety of business sectors in Australia. They importantly include: in mining about 65 companies; in commercial and service activities, 45; in petroleum, coal and chemicals, 30; in food, beverage and tobacco, about 25; in metal products, 25; in transport and storage, 15; in machinery and equipment, 10; in non-metallic mineral products, 10; in wood, paper and printing, 10; in construction, five; in water, sewerage and drainage, about five; and in textile, clothing, footwear and leather, five.

There was some consideration by the opposition that the potential school of companies to be picked up by this legislation is somewhat lower than that provided for by legislation in New South Wales and Victoria, but we decided to give the bill the opportunity of being put in place and tested for the purpose of trying to get some national leadership and pressure on business in Australia in the initial instance.

Business energy use accounts for over 80 per cent of Australia’s primary energy consumption. However, a relatively small number of businesses are responsible for the majority of energy use. ABS data suggests that the 250 large business energy users account for around 80 per cent of all energy used by businesses in Australia, which clearly points to where we have to make the initial progress with the application of this bill in trying to get an energy dividend as a result of government action.

Given the coverage of well over 50 per cent of emissions, the up-front compliance cost to business of an average of $49,700 per firm and current annual costs of $87,600 per firm, this seems reasonable coverage initially. It is for that reason we support the bill rather than seek to amend it with potential alternative legislation in New South Wales and Victoria. But we raise this issue in the debate for further consideration in the future based on how much progress we make as a result of this bill.

In the longer term, however, the opposition would like to see the program extended to cover a greater proportion of emitters. Estimated net benefits compared to business as usual are $557.3 million over 10 years, based on 2005 estimates. Realistically, businesses are unlikely to invest at such a low discount rate; however, with even more conservative assumptions including a 12 per cent discount rate, net benefits are estimated to be $132 million.

This bill is exceptionally important. I couch our remarks also about the issue of rising energy costs in Australia. I say that because, with very rapidly rising energy costs and increasing concern about the implications of climate change coupled with one of the most rapid economic expansions in history—namely, in our own backyard in China and India—it has become more important than ever for us to conserve our energy resources and to move on cleaner energy sources and technology.

In that context, in terms of energy, I pay brief attention to the issue of oil. At the moment, there are roughly five cars per thousand people in China—a growing economy, which will lead to increased demands for automobiles in that country. Alternatively, at the moment in North America, there are roughly 750 cars per thousand people and in Europe there are 500 cars per thousand people. In terms of the current debate on the price of oil in Australia, that confronts us as to what might occur in the foreseeable future. It is an issue of supply and demand. There is no simple answer to the issue of oil prices confronting not only Australia domestically at the moment but also, importantly, the international community.

Hence, in that context, we very seriously point the House’s attention to the need for the Commonwealth to get serious also about the issue of public transport in Australia. We have to front up to it in terms of our own responsibilities and our own capacity as a nation to move people and, for the movement of freight, to improve the use of rail transport in the decades ahead. This is a real economic issue and not just an environmental issue, if we are to be able to sustain good levels of employment and economic growth in Australia at a time when we are reaping the benefits of the rapid expansions of the Chinese and Indian economies, the benefits from which we want to continue to receive.

That goes to some of the primary issues and it also points to the fact that total energy consumption in Australia is 3,000 petajoules per annum and is estimated to cost $A40 billion annually. Industrial energy consumption is 40 per cent, giving an energy bill of $16 million per year. Although many firms now achieve impressive economic returns by using energy more efficiently, numerous studies continue to uncover significant potential. Experience in Australia and overseas has demonstrated that it is possible to save 10 per cent to 15 per cent of this energy use over a five-year program. This would result in reduced costs of up to $2 billion annually, strengthening Australian industry and making it more competitive in world markets. The opposition contends that there are very clear reasons, both for the purposes of our economy as well as for environmental, greenhouse and resource conservation imperatives, to get more out of energy use in industry and business.

That raises the importance of the second reading amendment, which the opposition proposes to move this morning in trying to focus the government’s attention on a broader agenda. Obviously, this second reading amendment is a practical endeavour to say to the Australian government that a little more has to be done, which means there should be a proper consideration of the House Sustainable cities report, on the question of our urban cities.

At point 3 of this second reading amendment, we seek to condemn the government for not adopting the bipartisan recommendations put forward by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage in its report Sustainable cities. That issue is raised because the truth is that, in terms of transport in Australia, it took a long campaign to get the Australian government to front up to the fact that we needed a national land transport plan. As a result of work done by the Department of Transport and Regional Development after the election of 2001, that finally emerged in the form of AusLink.

The problem is that, in the consideration of AusLink, the current government ruled out any consideration of urban public transport. It is not fair to say that, historically, the national government has not been involved in the provision of public transport in Australia. I can refer, for example, to programs such as the Better Cities Program which existed under Brian Howe, the then Deputy Prime Minister, as minister prior to the defeat of the Labor government in 1996. You can go around Australia and see the success of Commonwealth government action in improvements to public transport. For example, in Western Sydney around the Parramatta-Granville area, the extension of the tramway to Bundoora on Lower Plenty Road in Melbourne and the extension of the tramway down the Burwood Highway in eastern Melbourne. Clearly that was about the Commonwealth government accepting the issue of movement of people.

The huge cost of congestion now confronts state governments. In cities such as Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne there is a requirement for the Commonwealth to join in a proper partnership with local, state and territory governments and actually do something about improving access in our major cities. That is important because it is fair to say that the Commonwealth government has contributed to some of those problems with a migration program which effectively means that most migrants settle in our cities. Australia, more than ever, is depending on a migration program to attract skilled tradespeople to Australia because of our failure to invest in the training of Australians both in the trade skills area and at the tertiary level.

We use part (3) of our second reading amendment to say to the government that they need to step back from their original intentions with respect to AusLink and give some serious consideration to including public transport in future land transport planning in Australia. If they do not, they are going to damage Australia’s domestic and international competitive position. Congestion is now a huge cost to the operation of business in Australia. By way of example, there is the Western Sydney Orbital, which is finally being constructed as part of the national highway as a partnership between the New South Wales and Australian governments. The construction of that section of the national highway is going to represent a huge saving to the cost of running business in Australia. Currently, there is all the associated waste of time and oil with the approximately 55 sets of traffic lights. In the future, energy savings will be associated with the opening of that road. These are very serious issues. Part (1) of the second reading amendment reads:

item.para: calls on the Government to introduce energy efficiency to all sectors of the community, including transport, and housing, as well as business ...

speech.para: I do not think that it is fair in terms of energy efficiency and conservation to just point the finger at business. As a community, in our use of transport and in our personal activities, we have to start fronting up to fact that we have to conserve energy—in the same way that we have become serious in recent years about the issue of water conservation because of the drought in Australia. If we can do it successfully on the water front—and water is now accepted as a very important and scarce resource in Australia—we can adopt the same community attitude in our use of energy. The second, and final, part of the second reading amendment reads:

item.para: condemns the Government for failing to support the alternative fuel and renewable energy industries ...

speech.para: The opposition has had a long history in government of trying to encourage the development of those industries. In conclusion, I simply say on behalf of the opposition—there will be a long list of opposition spokespersons in this debate—that we support the bill before the House. We have not sought to amend the detail of it. We will be moving a second reading amendment to try and extend the government’s focus in a genuine way. We simply say to the government: ‘It’s a good start, but it doesn’t go far enough. We want you to consider this amendment.’ I commend the bill to the House and I move:

para.inline: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:

item.para: calls on the Government to introduce energy efficiency to all sectors of the community, including transport and housing, as well as business;
condemns the Government for failing to support the alternative fuel and renewable energy industries; and

condemns the Government for not adopting the bipartisan recommendations put forward by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage in its report on Sustainable Cities”.

talk.start.para: (Hon. DGH Adams)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

speech.para: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 10.44 am to 10.57 am

talk.start.para: —The purpose of the Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005 is to provide a legislative basis for the Energy Efficiency Opportunities program, which was announced in 2004 in the government’s white paper Securing Australia’s energy future. We are a lucky country. Our lucky country has energy resources which are a source of considerable prosperity. Those resources bring Australia more than $24 billion a year in export income, and they provide access to low-cost energy for businesses and households. Those energy resources underpin our prosperity and our security. They mean industry and employment for Australians, but they are finite. We have to continue to learn to conserve and sustain them. That is why the white paper and this legislation, which results from the white paper, are so important.

speech.para: The white paper represents a comprehensive review of energy policies and approaches taken by the government as a basis for developing long-term strategies to protect our energy resources, our economy and our environment into the future. About 90 per cent of Australia’s energy is sourced from non-renewable fossil fuels. Demand is projected to increase by about 50 per cent by 2020, so it is obvious that we must learn to conserve energy and to use it more efficiently. We can try to educate people to look for energy efficiency as a criterion when purchasing new appliances. We can promote the construction of energy efficient buildings. We can use more efficient light globes. We can even try to get the kids to turn off the lights when the leave a room. It all helps, but it is not enough.

Over time, such measures will reduce domestic energy use, and of course it is important to continue to look for ways to do that. But for nationally significant reductions in energy use, we need to look at efficiency in the way energy is used by those who use it the most. We want them to use what they need to process their product, but we want them to use it carefully. Business use accounts for over 80 per cent of Australia’s primary energy consumption, and Australian Bureau of Statistics data suggests that the 250 largest business users account for about 60 per cent of all energy used by business. That means that 250 businesses use about 50 per cent of all energy used in Australia each year. I think that is a quite remarkable figure. Let me repeat that: about 250 companies account for about half of all the energy consumed in Australia each year. If these companies can find and initiate more energy-efficient processes which significantly reduce their usage, then that reduction must also have a significant effect on the national figures. It is a real win-win situation. The company gets to save money, and our energy resources and environment also benefit—Australia benefits.

So how do we get those 250 companies to reduce their consumption, to seek methods and processes to use energy more efficiently? One way of reducing demand for something is to tax it or make it more expensive. Another is to introduce penalties for exceeding particular limits, but there are very good reasons for rejecting both methods. Firstly, the increased price would be passed on to consumers and the cost of living would rise. Secondly, the government has no desire to penalise these businesses just because they are large or because their particular industry has high energy requirements; nor do we want them to produce less to avoid exceeding an energy limit. We are talking about businesses that are major employers, important to the economic welfare of Australia. They create employment, which has an enormous flow-on in creating other employment and business opportunities. Damaging those businesses would have a negative effect on our economic welfare.

What the government wants to do is encourage these businesses to actively seek ways and means to be more energy efficient, and to undertake them. The benefits are at least threefold: overall energy consumption is reduced, which affects energy sustainability; less energy use means lower emission levels, which is good for the environment; and lower energy use of course means reduced business costs.

The purpose of this bill is to establish a framework for mandatory energy efficiency opportunities assessments, and public reporting of the outcomes, by the highest energy using businesses—that is, those businesses using more than 0.5 petajoules a year. Most people would not have any idea what a petajoule is or what 0.5 petajoules actually means, and I must confess I would be among them; 0.5 petajoules is roughly equivalent to the electricity requirements of 10,000 households a year. At least once in every five years these particular businesses will have to, firstly, assess their energy use; secondly, identify any cost-effective opportunities for using that energy more efficiently; and, thirdly, report on the assessments and their response to any identified opportunities. It is not mandatory to act on the assessment, only to report on it. This legislation leaves them totally free to make commercial decisions regarding the implementation of assessment findings.

While we are making it mandatory for these high-energy users to be aware of possible energy efficiencies in their operations, any subsequent action is their own commercial decision. For instance, a business might find that it can save hundreds of thousands of dollars a year on electricity by replacing certain machinery. But whether or not it makes the necessary capital investment remains a normal commercial decision for that business.

You might well ask why the government needs to push business to examine ways of saving money. It is an interesting question. Over the past decade the Australian government has used a variety of voluntary programs to assist companies to identify energy-efficient opportunities. The most recent one was the Energy Efficiency Best Practice Program, whereby the government provided $10 million worth of assistance to companies wishing to work towards energy efficiency. At first the focus was on providing benchmarking and information, which really did not prove very effective. The program gradually evolved into much more practical assistance, with management coaching and workshops, with some quite remarkable results.

It is interesting to read the later case studies. They include a malting company which identified energy savings of 43 per cent, predominantly by changes to kilning. Another great example is the brewery which cut its refrigeration energy consumption by 35 per cent and has saved $500,000 per year—that is, half a million dollars—by changing how it chills its brew. The explanatory memorandum says that evidence from this and other programs suggests that many businesses can save 10 per cent to 30 per cent on their energy costs without reducing productivity. It says that experience of the EEBP shows that the provision of information is not enough because there are organisational barriers to be overcome. These barriers include risk aversion, short-term horizons, lack of cooperation between various managers and decentralisation.

A Productivity Commission inquiry survey over five years of 47 sites, each spending more than $5 million per annum on energy, found that 44 of the 47 sites—that is, 94 per cent—had no established energy management systems. The Energy Efficient Opportunities Program is aiming at changing that. Remember, these companies are spending more than $5 million each on energy. Just as one manager in a large organisation cannot ensure energy efficient operations without the cooperation of other managers, nor can the government effectively work towards reducing energy demand and lowering harmful emission levels without the cooperation of people and businesses, particularly those businesses with the greatest demand for energy. The federal government is already working closely with industry and with state and territory governments to maximise energy savings with minimal additional regulatory burden.

More efficient use of energy in Australia will not only help protect our environment—it could yield a $975 million improvement in our GDP each year. The Howard government is committed to protecting the welfare of our people, our economy and our environment, but we must all play our part: business, government, and individuals. We must continue to be careful of energy use and the environment in our everyday life—in the lights we use, in the appliances we buy, in the cars we drive and in how we design and construct our homes. I therefore commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, being from Tasmania, you are well aware of the effects of renewable sources of energy. Tasmania’s development and direction has been dominated by the hydro-electric companies which, in part, in past years has perhaps led to an undervaluing of energy saving. It is a bit of an irony. Tasmania, being so dependent upon hydro-electricity—a renewable source of electricity—as its major energy source, can be a great exemplar for the rest of Australia of how to tackle a number of the global problems that confront us. Whilst you and I may have differing views on matters to do with the greenery that grows—which is code for trees, which is code for forests—Tasmania is an interesting experiment in managing a sustainable environment and all the principles of sustainability.

speech.para: I would hope, given the advantages that Tasmania has, that things like this legislation—the proposals that the opposition would like to see the government going forward with to even a greater extent to move towards greater energy efficiency—may lead to a renaissance for Tasmania in the way in which industry can be encouraged to adopt these great opportunities.

My interest in this legislation is not only because of the elements in it. There has been adequate description of the way in which the energy Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005 will operate. It had its genesis in the government’s white paper Securing Australia’s energy future in June 2004. It will establish the Energy Efficiency Opportunities Program, as has been outlined. It will require corporations that use more than half a petajoule of energy per year to register. As indicated in the minister’s second reading speech, half a petajoule is equal to the electricity needs of 10,000 Australians households, at a cost of over $5 million. The paper has estimated that some 250 companies are likely to be involved. It will require those companies to assess the way in which they can tackle their energy needs over the five-year cycle of the program.

On behalf of the opposition, the member for Batman has moved a second reading amendment which indicates that the opposition does not decline to give the bill a second reading. It certainly urges the government to look at energy efficiency in all sectors of the community including transport and housing, as well as the corporations covered by this legislation. Our second reading amendment condemns the government for its failures in the way in which it has supported alternative fuel and renewable energy industries. The third point in the amendment is the one that really attracts me to the debate:

quote.para: (3) condemns the Government for not adopting the bipartisan recommendations put forward by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage ...

speech.para: The second reading amendment goes to the Sustainable cities report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage, which has been tabled in this parliament. Another inquiry report tabled in the last parliament, in November 2003, is titled Employment in the environment sector: methods, measurements and messages. In that report the committee, in a bipartisan way, under the chairmanship of the member for Dunkley, now the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, recommended that the Australian government:

item.para: Retain the Mandatory Renewable Energy Target;
Substantially increase the Mandatory Renewable Energy Target as part of a multifaceted approach to increase market demand for and supply of renewable energy; and
Implement a timely review of the Mandatory Renewable Energy Target for beyond 2010 with a view to furthering the uptake of renewable energy in Australia.

speech.para: At the time, as I have reflected in other debates to do with energy efficiency matters, there was a very strong debate in the coalition parties about this matter. It is right to say—this is not something that has been corrected on the public record—that at the time the then Minister for the Environment and Heritage, David Kemp, was rolled in cabinet. I know that many of the people I had the pleasure of working with on the environment committee were disappointed by the decision of the government to not push the envelope much further in regard to mandatory renewable energy targets, which was really disappointing.

As I say, when the House of Representatives committee looked at this matter in detail and discussed it with people in the community and in industry, we came to this recommendation in a unanimous fashion. I always say that one of the great things about the work of committees is that if we can come to an agreement—even if it reflects a consensus view that may reflect that there has been a bit of give and take and people have had to do away with some higher aims—and get unanimous decisions at parliamentary committees, it would therefore behove executive government to implement them. The parliament, as reflected in its opinions through parliamentary committees, could be confident that, even in a change of government, these things would go forward. That is the disappointment we see in ignoring the overwhelming view that we developed as a committee.

I am pleased to see that the honourable member for Moore is here, because he successfully picked up the chairmanship of the committee in this parliament. We had the re-referral of the sustainable cities inquiry, and Dr Washer was very accommodating in allowing us to further pursue the inquiry, not ignoring the work of the committee in the previous parliament but value adding to it. We made a trip to Western Australia, where we not only had a series of inspections but also took further evidence which added to the outcomes of the committee.

In our Sustainable cities report is a chapter that goes to issues of energy. Whilst not necessarily decrying the intent of the bill before us, the opposition is indicating, as a view of the Australian Labor Party, that on these matters we should just keep pushing and pushing and have higher aims. In fact, we were really critical of the white paper last year on whether it really had adopted a strategy that was going to see the outcomes that were necessary over a timetable that was necessary. The reason for doing these things is that, whilst it might be said that there is scientific evidence, for instance about greenhouse matters, that leads us to look at ways in which we can produce renewable energy without the release of greenhouse gases, if we do not act now and the majority view in the science world is correct, we will have lost the opportunity and we in this generation will have very much let down future generations in our stewardship of the globe.

In looking at some of the matters to do with a national approach to energy efficiency, the committee, in the sustainable cities inquiry, has set down a very comprehensive list of things we think the government should look at. In fact, recommendation 27 says:

quote.para: The committee recommends that the Australian Government further develop its commitment to energy sustainability, particularly in the area of increasing the use of renewable energy.

speech.para: Recommendation 28 says:

quote.para: The committee recommends that the Australian government, through the National Framework for Energy Efficiency, examine the economic and environment benefits of decentralised energy delivery and encourage investment in this area.

speech.para: This is an interesting proposition—that the way in which we have this large decentralised system of energy supply runs in a countervailing way to our intent of achieving energy efficiency. Another view was put to the committee that the costs of shifting away from a large-scale centralised system to a decentralised system might outweigh the benefit, and that is why the committee recommends that we look at the economic and environmental benefits.

I want to highlight this one because I hope that, through the kind of legislation we are discussing today, we might see large corporations embracing the opportunities that might exist in their own processes to be creators of energy that might then be put out into the grid. Often, because this is incidental to the core business of companies, it is overlooked. We have to change the culture. We have to change the way people approach and think about these issues. That is why, again, we are pushing the government to show even greater national leadership on these issues, because a change is required in the approach of companies. The member for Fairfax was correct in proposing the question: why don’t companies do this? This is not a criticism, because they make decisions on the basis of their business.

We have to move forward—and the sustainable cities inquiry had this as an underpinning base—so that, in all facets of the community, we think more widely than just, say, economic sustainability, which a business might look at. Or the far Left greenies might just say, ‘It’s only ecological sustainability that’s important.’ At the end of the day, the sort of triple-line accounting that businesses are moving to is also something that is important about the national approach to sustainability. It has to be a national approach that not only is on the basis of environmental sustainability but includes economic sustainability and, as the committee emphasised, it has to include social sustainability, because the way in which all these things come together will be very important. We could have a dramatic effect if we do not change the way in which we envisage energy sources and energy use. That will have catastrophic social consequences as a result of the catastrophic environmental consequences, and we really have to look at these things.

This will require a change in our thinking. To the extent that this piece of legislation tells some 250—or so the white paper suggested—companies to change their attitudes and outlook because of legislation, this has to be transferred on throughout the community. Let us look at the types of companies that will be covered by this piece of legislation. If you extract data from the ABS, it indicates that there are something like 65 mining companies; 45 commercial and services companies; 30 petroleum, coal or chemical companies; 25 food, beverage and tobacco companies; 25 metal products companies; 15 transport companies; 10 machinery and equipment companies; about 10 non-metallic industry companies; about 10 wood, paper and printing companies; five construction companies; five water, sewerage and drainage companies; and five companies in the TCF industries. So you see that, across a whole range of industrial sectors, large companies will have to really come to grips with the questions and the challenges that are raised by the imposition of looking at the way in which they can be more energy efficient. I would hope that they are bold. I would hope that they see that this is not just a problem but an opportunity that they can embrace to be very innovative about the way in which they tackle some of these problems.

Again, Deputy Speaker Adams, if I refer to the forests and wood related industries, you know that I do acknowledge that those industries have been bold and innovative in changing their processes and in acknowledging that one of the thrusts that Australia requires is to go down the value added track, to be looking for those niche markets. When we can see a shift, a great change, in the way that industry approaches matters such as that, to add an approach that requires them to look at energy efficiency should not be a hard ask. But the simple facts are that, at the moment, Australia lags behind by international comparisons. The problem there is really this culture. It is not seen that this requires a partnership—that, at the individual level, this is truly about individuals and the state and that, at a company level, it is about corporations governance.

We have great challenges, but I think they add to the way in which the community can rally behind causes. To that extent, we need to have a wide debate on things like energy efficiency and the exploration of other forms of renewable energies, because it would seem that every form of renewable energy can raise the emotions. In a bold fashion earlier this week the honourable member for Batman, as our spokesperson on resources matters, entered the debate about uranium as a source of energy. I do not mind this being raised to the extent of increasing the debate. Without going into any confidences, in private conversations with the member for Moore we have discussed that we should not be afraid of the debate. It is not necessarily that if you put up your hand and say, ‘Have the debate,’ you have changed your mind—which I think is my position—but I cannot do my job as a legislator or as a person involved in public decision making if from time to time we do not revive the debate. At the moment I am sure that, even given the sorts of changes that people might propose in the debate, my position will not change. But I am obliged to keep an open mind and allow the debate.

We have extraordinarily emotional debates about wind turbines. The honourable member for McMillan—and I think he is on the speakers list—takes opportunities in these debates to express his concern about them. These concerns range from amenity and that they are a blot on the landscape, through to the way in which they are a great threat to migratory birds and the like. But we really have to look at the opportunities that evolve. The member for O’Connor may be on the speakers list. When he gets in here I am sure that tidal power will be discussed. We have interesting discussions about tidal power. A pilot program in Wollongong, in the Illawarra region, is being explored which perhaps has greater possibilities than the ones that we have seen on the western coast.

We need to look at all these possibilities. To that extent, we want to see the government push the envelope in that direction, and that is the reason for our proposed second reading amendment. I hope that when this legislation is in place it will lead to these big companies, these major decision makers in Australia who do things that affect the wider community, understanding the need for a cultural change. It is important for decisions to be made now that will affect future generations.

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Scullin for the excellent work he did in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage, and I thank him for his kind words.

speech.para: The Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005 establishes a program under which corporations that are large energy users are required to assess the potential to improve their energy efficiency and report publicly on the assessment. This measure was announced in the energy white paper entitled Securing Australia’s energy future in June 2004. The government has appropriated $16.88 million over five years to introduce the program. Ongoing but reduced funding will be required to continue administration of the program in subsequent years. In talking about energy efficiency, I am referring to gaining the same or a higher level of useful output using less energy input.

A major challenge to Australia’s economic growth and living standards will be to meet a projected 50 per cent increase in energy demand, while moving to a low emissions future by 2020. Improvements in energy efficiency will be a key step towards meeting this goal. It is expected that firms would take up cost-saving energy efficiency opportunities without any need for government intervention. Obviously, firms that use large amounts of energy would have a particular incentive to increase energy efficiency and reduce their input costs.

So why is the government getting involved? In reality, it has shown that, in Australia as well as overseas, there is often a gap between best practice energy efficiency and actual practice. In Australia, both the level of energy efficiency and the rate of improvement since 1973 are lower than those of other major industrialised countries. This may be due to the lower energy prices in Australia, which reduce the commercial attractiveness of some energy efficiency opportunities. However, the US and Canada have similar energy prices to ours and have had greater improvement in energy efficiency.

A Productivity Commission inquiry conducted this year found that 94 per cent of Australian companies had spent over $5 million on energy and did not have established energy management systems. The potential to improve energy efficiency in this country is enormous. The Australian government’s Energy Efficiency Best Practice Program has indicated that businesses could save up to 10 per cent to 30 per cent of their energy costs without reducing their productivity. The former Energy Efficiency Best Practice Program assisted industry sectors to achieve energy efficiency through innovation and capacity building. The program was funded from 1998 to mid-2003 and it worked with companies in the sectors of baking, beverage, packaging of dairy, pulp and paper, resource processing, supermarket and wine industry. To ensure that the materials, methods and results of the program continue to be available and utilised by industry, an internet based resource kit is being prepared.

So why are more Australian businesses not taking up energy efficiency opportunities, if they will save on costs? It would appear that large energy users lack information about energy efficiency opportunities within their own organisations and, therefore, are failing to take advantage of potentially cost-effective instruments. Previous government programs have focused on provision of information; fact sheets and other material were made available to industries regarding energy efficiency best practice. However, reviews show that the passive provision of information by itself did not assist companies seeking to improve their energy efficiency.

This bill requires a more active engagement by asking large energy-using firms to look at their unique energy circumstances, assess where improvements could be made and report on them. The bill seeks to enhance the information flow to decision makers in these organisations. It does not mandate an adoption of an energy efficiency investment if the firm privately does not consider it cost effective. This approach strikes a sound regulatory balance by helping to address organisational informational barriers, which may then lead to lower energy use and reduce environmental externalities when—and only when—it is of benefit to the individual firm.

Companies to be covered by the bill are those that use over 0.05 petajoules—that is 10 to the power of 15—in a year, which equates to the electricity needs of 10,000 Australian households with a cost of over $5 million. Around 250 companies in Australia meet this criteria. These 250 companies account for around 60 per cent of all energy used by business in Australia. Small improvements in energy efficiency in this sector will have a great impact on total energy use in Australia—much greater than changes of a similar magnitude in the residential sector would have.

These companies will be required to register for the program by mid-2007. By mid-2008, 50 businesses will have made an assessment and reported publicly on their energy efficiency opportunities. Verification and reporting arrangements will be determined consultatively. However, reporting is intended to utilise the Greenhouse Challenge Plus online reporting system, which already has about 120 of the target companies reporting on greenhouse gas emissions and energy. It is expected that companies will conduct assessments on a five-year basis from 2007. Public reporting is designed to provide the business community with useful lessons learned, while protecting companies’ reasonable commercial interests. Key performance indicators have been designed so that the program can be reviewed for effectiveness and efficiency.

It must be remembered that the Energy Efficiency Opportunities program has a dual purpose. The increased take-up of private cost-effective energy efficiency improvements will benefit not only the individual company but both the Australian economy, through increased productivity, and the environment, through reduced greenhouse emissions associated with less energy use.

The world abounds with proven ways to use energy more efficiently. Over the past decade, chemical manufacturer DuPont has boosted production by nearly 30 per cent but has cut energy use by seven per cent and greenhouse gas emissions by 72 per cent, thus saving more than $US2 billion so far. In 2001, oil giant BP met its 2010 goal by reducing carbon dioxide emissions to 10 per cent below the company’s 1990 level, cutting its energy bill by $US650 million over 10 years. Earlier this year, General Electric vowed to raise its energy efficiency by 30 per cent by 2012 to enhance shareholder value.

With US companies implementing energy efficiency opportunities, the US now uses 47 per cent less energy per dollar of economic output than it did 30 years ago, effectively lowering costs by $US1 billion a day. There are obviously countless ways that a company can become more energy efficient, ranging from simple, cost-free measures to those more complex, such as infrastructure changes. Many energy-efficient products, once costly and exotic, are now inexpensive and commonplace. Simple items—such as fluorescent lamps, which use 75 per cent to 80 per cent less electricity than incandescent bulbs—are now cost-effective options.

Products with poorly designed standby circuitry lose electricity by energising computers and other appliances when they are turned off. In the US it is estimated that five per cent of household electricity is lost in this way and that it is equivalent to the output of more than a dozen 1,000-megawatt power stations running at full tilt. The Australian government is increasing the availability of information on the energy performance of appliances, buildings and vehicles, which will make it easier to select energy-efficient models. It will also expand on the successful minimum energy performance standards program by applying it to a greater range of appliances and applying more stringent standards to equipment currently included.

Structural engineering can have enormous impacts on energy efficiency. For example, in 1997 a carpet factory was constructed in Shanghai with the concept of optimising the whole building for multiple benefits rather than using isolated components for single benefits. The designers cut the pumping power required for a heat-circulating loop by 92 per cent through two simple changes. The first was to install fatter or wider pipes rather than thinner ones, which greatly reduced friction and hence allowed the system to use smaller pumps and motors. The second innovation was to lay out the pipes before positioning the equipment they connected. As a result, the fluid moved through short, straight pipes instead of tracing circuitous paths, further reducing friction and capital costs.

Whilst on the topic of energy efficiency, it is worth while touching on sources of energy in Australia and increases in efficiency in this area. When it comes to energy sources in Australia, the key component is coal. It provides us with 85 per cent of our electricity. The amount of electricity—that is, energy—that can be generated from a tonne of coal today would have required over four tonnes 100 years ago, and this is constantly being improved upon. Australian scientists have recently developed a drying process that removes more than 70 per cent of the water from brown coal, boosting energy efficiency and reducing greenhouse gas emissions by a third or more. The captured water can also be used to replace some of the water requirements in power stations, such as cooling water make-up and ash pond water.

The Australian government is very keen to increase the uptake and efficiency of renewable, low-emission energy production. Currently, renewable sources supply around five per cent of our primary energy needs. In talking about renewable, low-emission technologies in the past, most people do not think of energy efficiency. However, if the renewable energy technologies are supported and are being researched and utilised, they will be further developed to become more energy efficient. More than $300 million was made available to support the renewable energy industry over the period from 1998 to 2004. This included a package of programs announced in the Prime Minister’s 1997 ‘Safeguarding the future’ statement, and additional support measures announced in May 1999 as part of the Measures for a Better Environment statement.

These measures included the Mandatory Renewable Energy Target, which mandates an increase in the contribution of renewable energy to Australia’s electricity supply mix to achieve a target of 9,500 gigawatt hours per annum by 2010. This measure is expected to generate at least $2 billion in renewable energy investment in Australia and will be a significant driver of the industry’s growth. The measures also include the Renewable Energy Commercialisation Program, which provides funding for renewable energy commercialisation and includes a component for industry development; the Renewable Energy Equity Fund, which provides venture capital for small, innovative renewable energy companies; the Renewable Remote Power Generation Program, which will fund special purpose grants to state and territory governments to provide rebates for the installation of renewable energy equipment where it will reduce the use of diesel fuel for electricity generation; and the Photovoltaic Rebate Program, which will increase the utilisation of photovoltaic systems on residential buildings and community use buildings.

Some important low emission technologies such as solar and wind are intermittent in their power supply. Better electrical storage is required for them to be more efficient. The government is establishing an $18 million fund which will provide funding on a competitive basis to leverage investments into development of advanced electricity storage technologies, such as advanced batteries, electromechanical storage such as flywheels and chemical energy storage.

An excellent example of an energy efficient renewable energy source is the solar Stirling generator. This unit was developed in response to the need for an uninterrupted power supply at a remote Queensland mine site. The unit combines the simple efficiencies of early 1800s Stirling engine technology with an inventive spin on conventional solar and heat cell technologies.

The Stirling engine was developed in 1816. It converts heat into usable mechanical energy via a drive shaft by the heating and expanding and cooling and contracting of captive gas such as helium or hydrogen. This engine is far more efficient than an internal combustion engine.

The solar dish used on the unit is constructed of polished stainless steel rings that can be produced for about $1,700, compared to the $10,000 to $12,000 for a conventional dish. Conventional dishes are also susceptible to UV degradation and damage from hail. This design also has a larger solar capacity than a dish of equivalent square area. Attached to the solar dish is a phase-change heat cell containing salt and graphite. This cell can store 9½ times more energy than the same size lead-acid battery used in photovoltaic systems. It can also store 100 per cent of the solar energy directed into it, compared to only 15 per cent for photovoltaics. The salt cell lasts in excess of 25 years.

When the engine is connected to a five-metre solar dish and salt cell, it can produce five kilowatts per hour and 20 kilowatts per hour of hot water at a combined heat and power efficiency of 80 per cent. This would be enough to cover domestic electrical and hot water needs and an absorption chiller for airconditioning, with energy storage for approximately four days without sunshine. The only by-products are hot water and electricity. A single unit will repay its CO footprint—that is, the amount of CO generated in its production—within 18 months. A desalination unit can also be attached which will supply 300 litres of distilled water per hour, 24 hours a day, and latent heat which is siphoned off and reused. The whole system is expected to retail for about $15,000 with government grants.

The Australian government is dedicated to improving Australia’s energy efficiency performance. This bill is part of a group of measures being undertaken in order to achieve this. They include demonstrating the potential benefits of energy efficiency and market reform through major Solar Cities trials; expanding the range of appliances and buildings subject to minimum energy performance standards; continuing to improve the energy efficiency of Australian government agencies; increasing the availability of information on energy performances of appliances, buildings and vehicles; establishing the Productivity Commission inquiry to provide further information on the potential benefits of and policies to achieve improved efficiency; continuing to work cooperatively with the states and territories through the National Framework for Energy Efficiency process; and improving price signals for demand side management as part of reforming Australia’s energy markets. Some price signals and market arrangements do not fully value the benefits from energy efficiency, either as a mechanism for addressing greenhouse emissions or by reducing energy demand in response to higher prices. A prosperous and sustainable economy needs all participants to play a part. This bill will enable big energy users to play an active role in making Australians’ futures better.

talk.start.para: —It is an honour and a privilege to follow my good friend the member for Moore, Mal Washer, in this debate. In the last parliament we were on the Standing Committee on Science and Innovation and also on the Standing Committee on Industry and Resources. It has been a loss to our committee that he is not on the industry and resources committee now, because one of the areas that we are looking at is the whole question of how to increase energy efficiency and also the safety of the community, and reduce greenhouse gases, by looking at alternatives to the use of fossil fuels. We are also looking at the general question of the state of Australia’s uranium industry and associated questions of nuclear power use in the rest of the world. I will come to part of that a little later.

speech.para: The member for Moore, as he is wont to do, had some really interesting things to say about how energy efficiencies could be achieved and what cutting-edge technologies had been developed in Australia and advanced to do things not just at the business level but at the home level. The Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005 is specifically directed towards energy efficiency opportunities for Australian businesses. There is absolutely nothing whatsoever here about domestic use, domestic savings and domestic efficiencies. I wish in this instance that the government had paid greater attention to the member for Moore and to the government members of the Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage, which in August 2005 produced Sustainable cities—I will come to that later as well—because what is not in this bill are important things that are dealt with in the amendment moved by Martin Ferguson, the member for Batman, our shadow minister in this area. I want to come later to some of the key elements of that.

In terms of what is instructive about how we have got to this point and why this bill is necessary, I am indebted of course to the Parliamentary Library and their Bills Digest and to the background briefing from the shadow minister’s office. Essentially we are here because in 1992 the then Labor government, in conjunction with state governments across Australia, initiated the process through COAG of putting before the Australian people and Australian governments an implementation process to try to get greater energy efficiency across Australia. In the 13 years since 1992 there have been some signal victories in regard to programs introduced by the states. Victoria, in particular, is an extremely interesting example of how you can go down a regulatory path and achieve significant effects—I think it is in the order of 1.15 million tonnes of CO a year because of what they have done. They are also very interesting because they have done what is not done in this bill—they have actually benchmarked what businesses have to do.

Maybe the government might move towards that kind of approach, because they have moved a long way so far. Upon coming to government in 1996, in the period 1996 to 1997 and a bit after that they started to look at how to deal with the problem of the greenhouse challenge. One of the problems, as the member for Scullin indicated, is that, even such a short period of time ago—nine years—it was still not absolutely conclusive that the arguments in regard to greenhouse were as strong as they now seem to appear. At that point in time it was apparent, particularly just a little bit later with George W Bush coming to the American presidency, that the approach taken by the Americans was to say that they did not want to trammel their industry in any way because of just the possibility of these greenhouse effects, and that really they would just barge on in the way that they had previously. They have learned some lessons in the interim.

The member for Moore cited some very interesting statistics on savings from energy efficiency in American businesses and the fact that this is cost effective. Those statistics underline one of the problems that the government have had, having spent a long time looking at what greenhouse strategies there might be and then encouraging businesses that it is in their own interest and in the country’s interest to do assessments of energy efficiencies that could be achieved. Specifically, in June 2004, the Prime Minister was still at it in securing Australia’s energy future. He said:

quote.para: ... the government will require large energy users to undertake a rigorous assessment of energy efficiency opportunities every five years ...

speech.para: But you have to go a lot further than that. This bill finally goes a lot further, because the government have discovered that in this area, as we discovered in the superannuation area when we were in government, you can talk until you are black in the face but sometimes important regulatory changes that have to be made have to be mandated.

If those who are covered by government regulation choose not to take the simple solution to follow the government’s strong suggestions that it is in the national and international interests, as well as in the interest of businesses, to look dramatically at how they could achieve greater cost effectiveness for their businesses and greater energy effectiveness for the benefit of the community at large, sometimes you just have to move. We are seeing here where the government have moved to.

There is also the example of where the government have not moved to. They have not moved to a point where they will say, ‘We will not only determine that major companies have to make energy savings; they have to be benchmarked.’ The government are good at benchmarking. The National Commission of Audit said on the government’s instruction, when it came out in 1996, that the only thing a federal government should do is benchmark and audit. The government have made a great deal of progress over a nine-year period towards getting themselves out of the game of actually governing this country, but at least through this issue they have been forced back into doing something active in this area.

But there is a let-out clause. If the business think that it is not cost effective for them, they do not have to travel down that road. I predict that the government will have to get harder in this area. If you do not press it to the floor, ensure that people have a regulatory regime—if you do not have well-founded policy, as is the case in Victoria and New South Wales—and make them do it, it is easier to just not do it.

Let us have a look at who is involved. When we look at the series of campaigns we have had—we have had them particularly in New South Wales on domestic use—we see that the big users of energy in Australia are in manufacturing. The ABS had a look at 250 companies that will be covered by this measure. Mining has about 65 companies; commercial and services, 45; petroleum, coal and chemicals, 30; food, beverages and tobacco, 25; metal products, 25; transport and storage, 15; machinery and equipment, 10; non-metallic mineral products, 10; wood, paper and printing, 10; construction, five; water, sewerage and drainage, five; and textile, clothing, footwear and leather, about five. Those companies account for about 80 per cent of Australia’s energy use in those areas, but the ABS then went on to find that a small number of businesses are responsible for the majority of that use and that those 250 business users accounted for 60 per cent of all energy used by business. The ABS also pointed out that there would be a significant cost of compliance for these measures, so companies would have to front up with roughly $49,700 per firm and pay recurrent annual costs of about $86,700.

You can see why the government was so tardy in coming to regulate—because of those costs. But on the other end there is a net benefit to those businesses, and that has been calculated to be in the order of $557.3 million over a 10-year period. But it may be a lot less than that. Due to a variety of factors, it may be only as much as about $132 million.

We welcome the fact that the government have finally moved from ineffectively cajoling to regulating and mandating, but we think they could actually do a great deal more. Not only are there energy efficiency opportunities; there are positive ways in which companies could do a great deal more than they have done so far. We also understand that there is a hell of a lot more that you can do if you take up the recommendations of parliamentarians. The Victorian example is very strong if you actually go a lot further. I will give the House a bit more information in that regard.

The Victorian Environment Protection Agency, the EPA, have conducted a program for greenhouse gas emissions and energy efficiency in industry. In part, that requires certain entities that operate under EPA statutory approvals to examine and implement measures to improve energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The legislative requirement to implement measures that meet certain benchmarks, money relating to the pay-back period, distinguishes the Victorian program from the proposed Commonwealth Energy Efficiency Opportunities Assessment program. That is the fundamental difference. They are willing to press it further and to go harder than this government is. There is a three-year implementation period from 2004-2006. Their expectation is that they will achieve 1.15 million tonnes of reduction of CO annually. Under that program, they have actually brought the stakeholders directly to account.

It is often good to take note of the work that government committees do and that individual members do. I am pleased to see that the digital clocks that were so inappropriately stolen from this chamber by one committee that decided it would do things without asking the users what was appropriate have been returned. I note that the rather ugly analog ones that they put in their place and that are a bit difficult to read have been left there. In energy efficiency terms the old clocks should go. The old analog stuff should be ripped out of this place. We should only have the more energy efficient digital clocks in this Main Committee on their own. That would be a saving in itself. That is a minor example, but a simple example of a small thing that we could do. I hope that might be taken note of.

Members from both sides of the House did excellent work on the report Sustainable Cities. What have the government done so far? Zip. Hopefully, they will move quickly to have a look at the recommendations in that report. I want to go to a couple of those, because they are pretty significant. The member for Moore spoke to recommendation 26, that the Australian government should double the photovoltaic rebate to further encourage the uptake of photovoltaic systems, based on the excellent work being done by the University of New South Wales. Recommendation 27 is very interesting. It is pertinent in regard to how we got to this bill and the tardiness of the government in pressing things through. It urges that the House:

quote.para: The committee recommends that the Australian Government further develop its commitment to energy sustainability, particularly in the area of increasing the use of renewable energy.

speech.para: It is telling that a cross-party committee have sent the message that they do not think the government has had much commitment to energy sustainability. I do not think they have. Part (3) of the amendment moved by the shadow minister, the member for Batman, urges that the House:

quote.para: condemns the Government for not adopting the bipartisan recommendations put forward by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage in its report on Sustainable Cities.

speech.para: Key to the amendment is the second part, which:

quote.para: condemns the Government for failing to support the alternative fuel and renewable energy industries;

talk.start.para: (Mr Baldwin)—I would remind the member that the next item of debate in this chamber is actually that report from the Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage. You should show a direct link to this bill, the Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005, rather than debate the report.
—Absolutely, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I bring that to your attention.

—Given that in this regard it is actually in the amendment, I can refer to it. I am not a member of the committee; I cannot speak to the report. But I can refer to it, as everyone else dealing with this has done—the member for Scullin did, of course—and I can refer to the recommendations it involves. It is entirely directed towards the issues covered in our amendment, and our amendment cannot be understood without the report being involved. So it is material in this instance.

speech.para: The first part of our amendment ‘calls on the government to introduce energy efficiency to all sectors of the community, including transport and housing, as well as business’. Recommendations 28 and 29 in the report go a great deal further. Recommendation 28 says:

quote.para: The committee recommends that the Australian Government, through the National Framework for Energy Efficiency, examine the economic and environmental benefits of decentralised energy delivery and encourage investment in this area.

speech.para: What has been apparent in the work that I have been involved in, both in the industry and resources committee and the science and innovation committee, is that we have not done enough in regional areas, in particular, to foster different energy uses and alternatives. One of the excellent examples given by the member for Moore is the work that has been done on the salt cell.

Through advice that has been given to our committee, I know that some really interesting work has been done by Australians in the CSIRO and in private companies. Some of the research has been done in disparate areas, but some very interesting work has been done gathering research done elsewhere and presenting it in a new way. In the case of one company that spoke to us, there is the possibility of providing energy not only in regional Australia but in urban Australia as well. They would provide not only peak-load energy but also base load energy, by combining three different technologies that people did not think would actually work together. Part of the solution is similar to what is involved in the salt cell—that is, you need a way to store what you generate.

Recommendation 29 of the committee goes to another area that we have been investigating in the industry and resources committee, and it is material in terms of ways of producing energy that have less greenhouse effect. Recommendation 29 says:

quote.para: The committee recommends the Australian Government investigate US and German initiatives in the area of solar energy generation and purchase, and, where appropriate, implement or emulate them.

speech.para: In the industry and resources committee, we heard that the original German work done on the solar tower worked reasonably well. A one-kilometre high solar tower was built in about 1982 in Spain and it went through 10 years worth of proving. A solar tower is essentially a big chimney, at the bottom of which is a very large base of solar cells gathering energy and being used to throw heat up that chimney. What has been done in Australia is quite extraordinary. They have taken that original German technique and reduced the tower in the first instance to a 350-metre tower that can produce about 250 megawatts. Instead of starting from that angle, they are looking now at going to much lower generation—12 through to 25 megawatts of power—using, again, a much smaller tower but with a much improved system of energy delivery and much greater productivity in terms of energy efficiency. Most excitingly, by using another technology that has been proven by the CSIRO in another area, there is the possibility that they might be able to marry this in such a way that they could store that energy, not only to feed in to produce further energy overnight but to produce base load energy that could be used throughout regional and urban Australia.

We need to be really inventive in this area and to be open to the massive opportunities that are available to us. We need to press not only the regulatory foot to the floor, as the Victorians have done, but also the inventiveness of CSIRO and our industries because, if we do not achieve these energy efficiencies and take up those opportunities, the country will be much the poorer for it.

talk.start.para: —It is an interesting thought that we are here today talking about efficiency. That of course is commendable on any occasion but, what is more, it makes a point that I have made, particularly during my time as minister for conservation, that the economy and the ecology have got to advance together. It is our responsibility as a government to ensure that the responses that we have to known environmental problems, for instance, can be resolved in a way that does not destroy our economy. If you want to know why that is the case, it is because poverty is the greatest threat to the environment. One does not have to travel far from our homeland to see the attitudes of low per capita income countries to the environment—it is virtually non-existent, because they cannot afford it. Unfortunately, the environmental debate is very much the property of wealthy nations; but that is not a reason why we should not have it.

speech.para: I am here today to argue a case—and, consequently, I have to say to the previous speaker, the member for Blaxland: I am not interested in mickey mouse solutions. I talk of ‘greenhouse with grunt’. Australia, in that primary energy resource area, has a great asset that is not available in many other parts of the world. It starts with the moon, which fortunately has a habit of circling the earth at a known and highly predictable rate. As a consequence its basic pull on the seas of the earth creates tides.
