When you get a certain topographical situation as exists in the Kimberleys of Western Australia, you get massive tidal movements of a mean average of 11 metres a day—up to 40 feet. They happen to move twice a day so, if you want to harness the massive energy associated with those tides, you can harvest it on the way in, on the way out, on the way in and on the way out.

We heard quite tragically some time ago of a number of cockleshell harvesters getting drowned by a quickly increasing tide in England. Of course, that is no help from an energy perspective because the fact that they were out there with their tractors on this gradually sloping beach means that you cannot effectively harvest the energy. But when you go up into the Kimberleys and look at Walcott Inlet, which is 50 old-fashioned miles long, fills up and empties twice a day and has a neck where water flows in and out, where the average 400-metre runner could traverse—or swimmer, when the tide is up—then you realise how easy it is to harvest that energy. It is probable that you could harvest it more than once up and down that same inlet.

As a consequence I asked CSIRO what they thought of the energy harvest potential of that resource. They answered: equal to all the energy of every variety consumed in Australia today. And we have never ever contemplated using it. There is one good reason for that: it is far away from where we need electricity in the Australian context, notwithstanding that there is a very large adjacent bauxite deposit there, which is the base material for aluminium, known otherwise as congealed electricity. One would wonder why, as I have put to the state government over there, there is not a condition on leasing that deposit that it has to be vertically integrated to aluminium, and the electricity to do so should be generated by the tides of the Kimberleys.

A more important development has occurred. Electric wires cannot efficiently deliver the energy generated to, say, Perth, South Australia or Sydney, but another energy transport medium could do the job. It is called hydrogen, one of the most commonly occurring elements in our universe. It is found, at a ratio of two parts hydrogen to one part oxygen, in water. It can be extracted from salty water as well as fresh water. A number of people, including our Prime Minister, may remember some of the experiments they conducted in their high school laboratories. They would have put two electrodes under low voltage into a beaker of water and got hydrogen off one and oxygen off the other.

The opportunity now exists to use the massive resource in the Kimberleys not only to generate electricity, which might develop the northern area—a good idea—but also to extract hydrogen and liquefy it, which would make it transportable, in the same nature as liquefied natural gas. We use natural gas to liquefy natural gas, so we burn some of the energy. Natural gas by nature usually has a component of carbon dioxide. In the gas one gets out of the Gorgon deposit the carbon dioxide component can be as high as 14 per cent. Some of the west Queensland facilities also have that level of contamination. The carbon dioxide has to be removed in the liquification process, simply because it solidifies before natural gas liquefies and, if you let that happen, your whole system blocks up. So what do they do with it? They pump it into the atmosphere and then send the clean product off to China or Japan or somewhere like that. In the case of Gorgon, they try to geosequester it—in other words, extract it and pump it back down into the ground.

I have some concerns about this policy. For instance, Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, in your own region were they to extract the carbon from coal after it is burnt to make electricity and pump it into the ground, and then were we to have another disastrous earthquake, it might be followed by a very large burp. The policy has a few problems, in my mind. Nevertheless, if we want a purely vertically integrated energy transfer agent—that is how hydrogen is referred to in the scientific community—how does that happen? If you generate electricity and you want to make it renewable you could use all the base surplus that occurs at night-time and other non-demand periods at a coal fired power station but you would have a carbon issue. If you want a purely renewable process you could commence using the tides of the Kimberleys to produce, as the French have been doing for 40 years, electric energy. Having done so, you electrolyse water and then you have a huge resource of energy which you can use to liquefy the hydrogen. You can then put it in a tank or tanker and take it to Sydney and use it there. I would not propose to use it to remanufacture electricity—although that is exactly what you can do.

In 1839 a gentleman invented the fuel cell, but it languished because petrol and diesel and similar fuels were that much easier. We have rejuvenated it. There are three buses in the Perth metropolitan area, three in London and 30 in various other parts of the world, in groups of three, running on pure hydrogen. They have no engine. You can put hydrogen into a reciprocating engine. BMW, in particular, followed that technological route. But in the case of the fuel cell you recombine this hydrogen with atmospheric oxygen and you get back the electricity you put into the water up in the Kimberleys.

So in fact the buses that are running around Perth, London and other parts of the Northern Hemisphere are running as electric buses. We immediately recombine hydrogen back to electricity and water. If you get behind one of these buses in Perth as they accelerate away and use more hydrogen, you see that a puff of steam comes out of the exhaust pipe. There is no pollution whatsoever.

The transport sector in Australia uses 50 per cent of all the energy consumed in Australia. We already have proven technology. Yes, it requires upgrading or further development. We could have a 50 per cent reduction in carbon based energy by the simple act of replacing that energy with hydrogen.

A lot is said about wind generation. Of course there are more poems and songs written about the vagaries of the wind than I could list in this place today in the time available to me. It is farcical to say that wind generation is saving emissions. It simply is not. Our base load coal fired power stations have got to maintain steam pressure while waiting for the variations in the wind.

I had discussions with the Minister for the Environment and Heritage this morning. Within my electorate a wind tower was erected for an isolated community. It is about 600 kilowatts. Then the power authority went out and bought two diesel generators of 700 kilowatts. Okay, they tell me that their fuel consumption is down by 45 per cent, but, on the other hand, if that wind generator were using its surplus power—remembering that typically the wind blows most strongly when all the lights are out—they could be making hydrogen and running the diesel motors on hydrogen. This morning an expert quoted all the great problems to me. You would think that we could not fly a man to the moon.

What I am saying is that we are wasting money trying to clean up coal. It may or may not work, but as we stand here the cost of extracting the carbons from the chimneystack of a coal fired power station will increase the price of electricity somewhere between two and five times. That is still a matter of dispute. We should be spending our research money on getting hydrogen into our transport sector, and if necessary we should be making it in the Kimberley.

My farmers should be making it on property. We should be assisting them with the research. I would like to know how big a photovoltaic cell panel and possibly wind generator my farmers need to electrolyse the salty underground water that is giving them all sorts of pain in terms of dryland salinity—to manufacture on 365 days a year enough compressed hydrogen to run their tractor and their header at peak periods and probably to top up the LandCruiser in the intervening period.

That is all quite practical. No-one is doing any research on that. We are just passing laws in the parliament. We should be efficient. That is where the money needs to be spent. That would fix the price. The only fuel of tidal power is money. Money is a lot damn cheaper than fuel at this point in time.

I recently visited Detroit General Motors. It is their view that within five years they will be manufacturing, mass producing, a hydrogen fuel cell car—a car running according to the same principle as those buses around all parts of the world. Where will Australia be at that time if we want to bring a heap of them out here to have a distribution system available and a source of hydrogen? We are doing nothing. My side is doing nothing. Let us admit it. I think the members opposite would say that they have never seriously asked that question.

The other thing that I was told in Detroit was that only 12 per cent of the population of the world own a motor car today. It is predicted that that will go to 16 per cent by 2020. By then the world population will have moved from six billion to eight billion. So it is not 16 per cent of the present world population; it is all those extras. We keep mucking around trying to improve the efficiency of petrol based cars, but they say that in fact you would need to improve the efficiency of petrol or diesel motors by 62 per cent to keep a flat curve on petrol consumption in the United States alone.

So let us look to the other alternatives. The present-day government, with the full support and enthusiasm of the opposition, should be saying: ‘We’ve got $500 million for research into renewable power. Why aren’t we asking one of our car manufacturers to produce a hydrogen taxi for the world?’ When you look at the technology of these cars, as General Motors will show you, it is all in the chassis. So you can have a floor plan much more like a London taxi, with plenty of room. In fact you would probably drive the car, because its steering would be electronic, with a joystick. So you could put that in the middle and it could be a right-hand drive or a left-hand drive with virtually no problems. You could have the taxi with plenty of room for your luggage, and step in. It may be a car of a similar nature that becomes the second family car, that is easy to put the kids in, that is easy to put shopping in and all those sorts of things.

More particularly, why can’t we as a government say to Holden, Toyota or someone, ‘You build this vehicle and we in conjunction with state governments and local government will mandate their use in Sydney, Melbourne and these other places’? While we are about it, why aren’t we designing a fuel cell component so that you can rip the back axle out of a two-tonne truck, which is also a major polluter around the metropolitan areas, and fit in one of these things? If I can come back to taxis for a minute, let us say that even with government subsidies these taxis cost $100,000 each. You would say, ‘You can’t impose that on a poor old taxi driver.’ What do they pay for the licence plates? They pay $500,000 if they are lucky. Wouldn’t it be better for Sydney to have a taxi fleet whose only emission was steam, which was a much more convenient vehicle and which of course had the convenience of having only a few centralised refuelling places.

The General Motors company say that for $12 billion to $15 billion they can put a distribution system for hydrogen throughout the United States. Yet someone will tell you, ‘It’s all too hard.’ Yes, development is needed if we want a totally clean fuel system or if we want to take 50 per cent of our energy consumption out of the hydrocarbon places completely. You can get hydrogen by splitting natural gas—but the first lesson you learn in secondary school physics is that you cannot destroy an element. You can pluck the hydrogen out of the hydrocarbon, but you have still got the carbon, and that is the polluting factor. Someone said: ‘That’s quite easy. When you do this and you strip the hydrogen out you end up with carbon monoxide.’ We all know that is how people poison themselves. Apparently you can burn that and you get carbon dioxide again. I thought that was the problem.

Why are we mucking around with that sort of technology when we know how to produce hydrogen? We have technology, including the reciprocating motor—and BMW have got them—that runs on hydrogen. Down in my electorate, at Hopetoun, they have got $1 million from us to build another wind tower. I said to the minister this morning, ‘Why don’t you insist that all the surplus energy of those two wind towers is directed to electrolysing water?’ You can buy a package. That is what fuels some buses in certain parts of the world. It all just sits in a container. Why aren’t we insisting that that go in concert? Why, after we have paid for another wind tower, which is highly inefficient in terms of its comparison with coal generation, aren’t we using it to make the hydrogen to run the diesel motors that are sitting there to back it up every time the wind slows down or the grid demand exceeds its capacity if it is up to capacity?

These are all fundamental issues that both sides of parliament should be looking at. A fuel cell is 61 per cent efficient; a reciprocating motor, in the mid-20s. So in other words we get a prize for being environmentally friendly, yet we are running around trying to tax people to force them to use less energy, when they could be using virtually three times as much with no pollution. This is the challenge that I ask the opposition to consider. In fact, if they get after us on it, I will welcome it, because I do not think we have gone anywhere near far enough in the proper solutions. We are waiting for the world to fix the problem and it might be too late.
Debate (on motion by Ms Owens) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —The night of 2 October 2005 will be a night that lives long in the memory of many people in south-west Sydney. It was a night that saw people from all walks of life gathered around television screens in pubs, clubs and family homes, all in one united hope—the hope that the mighty Wests Tigers would take out the NRL grand final. I am happy to report that they did, and in spectacular style. The streets of Campbelltown in particular, where I live, were abuzz for a week, with perfect strangers coming together in shops and on streets, contemplating the prospects of the Wests Tigers at the grand final. Cars were decorated with balloons and streamers; shop windows were adorned with posters; and the air was filled with a nervous expectation.

speech.para: It has been a long time since the western suburbs has won a premiership—1952, in fact—and it was back in 1969 when Balmain won a premiership. But this was the first occasion that the new five-year-old merged joint venture, the Wests Tigers, had made it to a grand final. Needless to say, in the days leading up to the grand final, supporters in the south-west of Sydney were already walking tall, looking forward to a great game and hopefully a great victory. That is exactly what we got: a great game, a tremendous victory and fabulous celebrations of the win. I do not know if the players have come back to earth as yet, but I do know that there is still a spring in the step of Tigers fans in the streets of Ingleburn, Campbelltown and Liverpool. It is amazing what a win like this can do for a local community like the one I represent.

There are a number of people who must be congratulated for taking the team from rank outsiders earlier in the season to a premiership win. Naturally, Scotty Prince and the players had a great deal to do with it, both the high-profile players and the not-so-high-profile players who toiled away tirelessly throughout the year and have become heroes in the community and examples to many aspiring young players who strap on their football boots every weekend.

Of course, a team is only as good as its support staff and Wests has been blessed with a fine coaching staff, led by Tim Sheens, himself no stranger to grand final success. To be honest, when I stood on the hill at Campbelltown Stadium with the Leader of the Opposition during my election campaign, watching Wests Tigers lose to the Canberra Raiders in a trial match, I did not think that I would see Wests Tigers making it to a semi-final let alone taking out the grand final. Tim Sheens and his coaching staff, strongly supported and encouraged by club officials, particularly the CEO, Steve Noyce, can be rightly proud of the results that they have now attained.

While the Lord Mayor of Sydney, Clover Moore, has decided not to put on a street parade to recognise the victory of this fine Sydney based side, I am proud to report that the West Tigers will lead a street parade through Campbelltown early in November. In fact, on 5 November the Tigers will lead more than 80 floats down Queen Street in the Festival of the Fisher’s Ghost street parade. The Tigers may not be considered good enough by the Lord Mayor of Sydney to have their own street parade, but they will certainly be greeted by thousands of cheering fans who will line Queen Street and congratulate their team. I will be one of those fans, and I am proud to say that this year, my team, the Wests Tigers, took out the premiership.

Congratulations to the players, the support staff, the administration and of course the fans on a superb effort this season. Let us hope that this time next year I will be proudly hanging the 2006 grand final-winning Wests Tigers T-shirt in the window of my parliamentary office.

subdebateinfo.title: New South Wales Pensioner Travel Discount

talk.start.para: —Last month, the New South Wales government announced that it will not be extending any travel concessions to pensioners living outside the Hunter, the Illawarra, the Blue Mountains and the Central Coast. Pensioners living outside those areas will not be able to take advantage of the $2.50 concession being offered to their peers. Instead they will continue to suffer a penalty for daring to live outside Labor electorates in New South Wales.

speech.para: This is a huge rebuff to pensioners living in the Southern Highlands and the Shoalhaven. The message the New South Wales government are sending to them is: ‘You don’t count, and we don’t care.’ The Labor Party have always been class conscious and what better way is there of reinforcing that ideology than by creating two classes of citizens in New South Wales—one that lives in the metropolitan Labor held electorates and one that includes all the others.

This just adds insult to injury when you consider that the electrification of the South Coast rail stops at Kiama. Of the $380 million the Labor government dedicated to the maintenance of the Princes Highway from Wollongong to the Victorian border over 10 years, well over half is being spent on constructing the Kiama bypass. The New South Wales government are also pumping water out of the Shoalhaven River to supplement Sydney’s supplies and are now suggesting that they may raise the wall of the Tallowa Dam in Kangaroo Valley. This will cause untold damage to what they have themselves promoted as heritage valued environment.

All in all, the approach of the New South Wales government to regional issues seems rather partisan. The state coalition, as part of their election platform a couple of elections back, suggested a universal pensioner travel concession of $1. This was costed and found to be fiscally viable. It would have applied to private bus operators, and many of my constituents who are pensioners would have benefited as it is a long way between towns and villages with little or no public transport. A shopping expedition to Nowra can be quite costly in fares, but that does not seem to concern the New South Wales government.

There is no reason why the $2.50 concession being offered to metropolitan pensioners cannot be extended to regional and rural areas. In fact, I challenge the New South Wales government to show why this cannot be the case. Why are pensioners in the Gilmore electorate being discriminated against? The purpose of an elected government is to govern for all, yet here we find a government who are blatantly saying that it is okay for pensioners outside the metropolitan areas to be treated differently. In the rural and regional areas, there is suffering because our pensioners are paying more to get around. It is tantamount to categorising them as second-class citizens.

I would have thought that, given the boundary redistributions for the next election, there would have been some token gesture to demonstrate the principle of universal suffrage. Instead, the member for Kiama, whose boundary redistribution will take in a nominally Liberal seat, is running around trying to convince people that he can look after them. But the evidence suggests something opposite. I am intrigued by how the member for Kiama can reconcile the obvious discrepancies between what he is saying and what is actually happening in the real world. Ironically, he has recently been appointed as the parliamentary secretary to the New South Wales Minister for Roads. That puts him in the box seat to demonstrate his influence and the regard in which he is held. The first thing he could do is to wield his new influence and get money for the Princes Highway. But I bet all we will get is more doubletalk and blame shifting and little action.

New South Wales has a population of just over 6.7 million persons. Most residents live in Newcastle, Sydney and Wollongong, whilst proportionally only about one-fifth live in the rest of the state. So how much more expensive would it be for the New South Wales government to extend the concession throughout New South Wales so that they do not discriminate against country people, as they always seem to do? The people of Bomaderry and North Nowra are entitled to an answer before the member for Kiama asks for their vote in 2007.

subdebateinfo.title: Victory in the Pacific Day Medallions

talk.start.para: —Over the past weeks it has been my great privilege to present over 150 medallions to veterans. This has been to mark the occasion of the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II in the Pacific. I am advised that in the seat of Banks there are over 2,500 veterans entitled to receive the medallion. Many have chosen to have it presented by their local member. I have been joined on each occasion by my colleagues Kevin Greene MP, the member for Georges River, and Alan Ashton MP, the member for East Hills. Their presence, together with the pleasure of the recipients and their friends and families, has made these occasions truly memorable.

speech.para: In some cases our veterans have been unable to attend the formal presentations that I have been conducting in the various service clubs in the electorate. I have been invited to visit some 30 homes to date, where I have been able to conduct personal presentations. Each time I hand a medallion to one of these people I know that there is an individual story behind that person and the memories they carry, both good and bad, of the years they served their country.

I recall one in particular. The medallion was accepted by a veteran’s son on behalf of his deceased father and at the request of his mother. The mother was especially pleased to ask her son to accept the medallion as relations between father and son, I am told, had never been easy. His mother explained why. The father had served several years on the Burma Railway and later in the Japanese coal mines. According to the veteran’s widow, her husband was never really the same when he returned to Australia. Who can blame him? It was moving to see how important the medallion was to mother and son. My generation know very little of what our veterans experienced and suffered. This is my opportunity to find out. I have enjoyed every minute of the seven formal presentations I have conducted so far, together with the many personal presentations.

However, it has come to my attention that there is a crucial anomaly in the process of determining the criteria for receipt of the medal. In speaking with the many veterans, widows and widowers, my staff have found that the Department of Veterans’ Affairs has made what I believe to be a strange determination. In a number of cases both husband and wife served during the war—indeed, that is how many of them met. Where both are still alive, each is entitled to receive the medallion. Where one is deceased, the family is only entitled to receive one medallion. In several examples, a woman has been allocated a medallion to receive on behalf of her deceased husband but is not entitled to receive one in her own right.

This seems to be inconsistent, at the very least, and discriminatory at its worst—although I have had the reverse apply as well, where a husband received a medallion on behalf of his deceased wife and was therefore not able to receive one in his own right. When queried the department explained that the policy is ‘one medallion per person’. If one partner is deceased then the other is entitled to only one medallion. I find this extraordinary. Both partners have served their country in their own right. Initially I was informed that the criteria for receiving a medallion were:

quote.para: ... a person must have been alive on 8 May 2005, Victory in Europe (VE) Day, and served during WWII, or be the widow/er of a person who served as:
A member of Australia’s defence forces; or
An Australian merchant mariner; or
A Member of the Commonwealth or allied forces who has qualifying service; or
An allied mariner who has qualifying service.
To be eligible for the medallion a Commonwealth or allied veteran, mariner, widow or widower must live in Australia.

speech.para: The fact sheet provided by the department states:

quote.para: Maximum of one medallion per person.

The medallion is intended to commemorate surviving WWII veterans and their widow/ers. One medallion will be issued to each eligible veteran or widow/er. Where a widow/er is eligible for a medallion in their own right as a veteran, and is also eligible for one as a widow/er, the widow/er will receive one medallion.

speech.para: It seems extraordinary that this should occur and that people are determined to be eligible based on their marital circumstances. These veterans contributed to the war in their own right, as individuals. The medallion represents the respect that this generation holds for those who have served in the defence of Australia.

A further query to the department elicited the response that the policy is under review by the national office. I do not know what stage that review is at. However, on behalf of a number of very disgruntled ex-servicemen and women, may I make it clear that they are not pleased. The Department of Veterans’ Affairs has a motto, which is on their website, which states: ‘Their Service—Our Heritage’. I do not believe that ‘our heritage’ is well served by such bureaucratic rulings. I strongly urge the department to reconsider this distressing state of affairs. If that does not occur, the minister must intervene in this matter and clear it up as soon as possible.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: —As we approach the Phillip Island Moto Grand Prix this weekend I want to raise two issues that affect that area. One is in relation to the public safety on the roads at Kilcunda and the second is in relation to public health issues on Phillip Island. The town of Kilcunda is on the Bass Highway. It has a beautiful vista; it overlooks the Bass Strait. But it has an extremely dangerous crossing. It is a primary route with trucks, busses and cars all travelling along it. Children are set down there, parents cross there and families who are staying at the caravan park cross that road on a frequent basis as a means of getting to and from the shops, the caravan park and the beach.

speech.para: This is a disaster waiting to happen. It is a blind corner with heavy traffic travelling at fast speeds through a small township that has a significant population of elderly and young people, both of whom are at risk from the traffic. We have made representations to VicRoads in relation to the desperate need for a pedestrian crossing. Those representations have not been responded to by the state, and I want to raise before this House on this day, with the Grand Prix coming up this weekend, that it is a death trap. Unless something is done to produce a pedestrian crossing at the earliest possible time, we face the risk of either elderly or young people, or others, being killed on a road which should be perfectly safe. A pedestrian crossing is needed now. We have a petition in place and, in working with the local community, my message is very simple: we will continue to work until we are successful, and nothing less than complete success in securing a pedestrian crossing will satisfy us.

The second point I want to make is in relation to the need for a Phillip Island aquatic centre. As we approach the Grand Prix weekend, with tens of thousands of visitors going to Phillip Island, one thing which is absolutely clear is that there is a need for a major aquatic centre for residents and visitors. The reasons are twofold. The first is that residents in an area that is demographically old have a need not just for aquatic facilities but, in particular, for hydrotherapy. To that end, the Phillip Island Aquatic Centre Steering Committee, led by Pam Cameron, has developed a proposal which is a ripper. This proposal sets out a plan for an aquatic centre, a funding mechanism for it and a hydrotherapy proposal. It is one with which I have been involved since shortly after its beginning, and it is one to which I am committed. I commend the committee in relation to their activities.

The second reason why it is necessary is that Phillip Island has uneven tourism throughout the year. It has high points for the major road races and it has high points over summer, but there are long periods where the level of tourism to this magnificent island—with its penguins, its koalas and the attraction of the Nobbies—is down. One of the elements which tourism advisers have said would help smooth that is a major aquatic centre, because there is great interest from sporting teams, schools and others in coming to the island, training there and visiting the natural environment, if there are facilities of sufficiently high standard to help with sports, the entertainment of school groups and the entertainment of visiting tourists, whether from Victoria, Australia more broadly or overseas. What we have at present is a large number of day tourists who come in, visit the tremendous Phillip Island Nature Park and leave. We want to capture that market. We want to make sure that those people stay more than one day, that they stay overnight or for a weekend.

An aquatic centre would be a tremendous addition for the residents and it would be a great step forward for tourism. The steps in achieving this are simple. We have a plan. We need the support of the council, and we recently met with the mayor. I have pledged to push it at the federal level as a significant program, and we need the state to come on board. Those are the steps forward. I commend the aquatic centre proposal, and I pledge to do all I can to help. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I note a report in today’s Australian by Cameron Stewart wherein the President of the Australian Federation of Islamic Councils, Ameer Ali, retracted comments that he made in the last fortnight. Having been briefed as part of the government’s Muslim Reference Group, he then greeted reporters with the comment:

quote.para: It was all unanimous; not one single disappointed person.

speech.para: In today’s Australian he roundly turns and, after exposure, concedes that the matter was not discussed amongst the parties there. It is quite clear from the comments of a number of participants that there is anxiety amongst members of the government’s Muslim Reference Group on the grounds of human rights issues. Ameer Ali conceded, ‘That was a misunderstanding. What I meant was—’ et cetera.

This unfortunately is not the first occasion on which the government has suffered some embarrassment from the performance of the Muslim Reference Group. In the first place, the group causes some concern. The criteria should not be how close people are to a political party or how much they might be perceived as giving the statements that the government might be comforted by, because this is the second time we have had a significant retraction.

The infamous Mr Deen, who of course is a well-known supporter of the federal coalition—and that is a credential, apparently, to be on the Muslim Reference Group—is the person who in the early meetings made the blatantly racist comment that all of the Jews in New York were away from work on the day of the September 11 attacks. That of course was a slander which originally apparently came from the chief imam in Paris some years ago. Mr Deen of course also had to clarify things. This is a person put on the Muslim Reference Group for the whole community in this country, handpicked by the Prime Minister. He said, ‘Oh, I didn’t really want to articulate those views. I was just repeating what other people think.’

Quite frankly, I have doubts about his later defence. It is very unconvincing. But again, as I say, it indicates problems with the people in this reference group. From day one this group has not represented Islamic Australia. It is ethnically not of that tune. I of course represent a significant number of Turks in Western Sydney. I am very close to the community; I often attend the mosque there. If you want a community in this country with a secularist, progressive line in regard to the future of Islam, it is the Turkish community. They have not one representative on this body.

Similarly, the Lebanese Muslim association, which centres around the mosque at Lakemba, is not represented. These people might be now led by a more religious group of people than they have been historically. In the Lebanese Muslim association, there have been faction fights in the mosque, and the current leadership would be perceived as being more orthodox, more religiously committed, than their predecessors perhaps. But that is not criteria for exclusion.

We have to make sure in this country that we take the vast majority of Muslims with us, that we have them committed to Australia and its interests et cetera. If we have a committee which does not represent them and if we have a tune coming from some government members and ministers that those that are excluded are the ones that are dubious and doubtful, the ones that perhaps have some difficulties, then we have a situation where unfortunately misunderstanding and concern are spread in the community.

On 29 August I had the Prime Minister in my electorate. The only place he seems to ever attend in my electorate, besides sporting events, is the Al-Faisal College, where he shares a close friendship with the principal, Shafiq Khan. I concede the point that he and others make in some venues—not all the time, mind you—that this government has indeed greatly enhanced the proliferation of Islamic schools in this country by liberalising the rules with regard to the establishment of schools. Previously, under Labor, there had to be a test as to how it would affect the local government schools. That was abandoned and other rules were liberalised. The Prime Minister and others, the member for Mitchell and the Attorney-General, in Muslim venues make the point that the government’s funding for private schools is very supportive of the Islamic community.

The day he visited, I took the opportunity to make the point in front of the Prime Minister that Islamic Australia is essentially like the rest of Australia, to a large extent. I gave an example of seven people in my electorate and people connected with me who are out there in sport, in culture, in professions, in education et cetera making a commitment to the country.

So I have some concerns about the nature of the Muslim Reference Group. Let us make sure that these groups represent the whole community. Let us make sure that, by exclusion, people who do carry clout, people who do matter in this country, are not perceived as being outside the circle, perhaps not as loyal as others, not as true to the government and therefore liable to cause difficulties.

talk.start.para: —The Hinkler electorate’s educational institutions and schools have long been known for their innovation and dedication to providing the best possible learning environment for their students. That commitment has been matched by strong support from the Australian government, with more than $1 million recently allocated to state school projects throughout Hinkler under the Investing in Our Schools Program. The IOSP has been warmly welcomed by local schools and P&Cs, many of which struggle to find funds for wish-list projects such as airconditioners, playground equipment and new computers.

speech.para: I remember back to last year’s election, when my local newspaper was inundated with outraged letters from various education unions, claiming that the coalition government had been diddling state schools on funding. However, the federal funding to Queensland state schools increased by 5.4 and 4.8 per cent in the previous two years, while over the same period the state government funding increased by only 2.4 and 3.9 per cent respectively. If the state government had merely matched the Commonwealth’s percentage increases, state schools would have received another $116 million, an extraordinary figure.

The coalition has come through with the goods well and truly. These goods are worth $700 million in direct funding for capital works in state schools between 2006 and 2008. That amount comes on top of the $1.5 million already allocated by the Australian government for schools’ capital works over the next four years. Some of the specific projects in my electorate that will be able to proceed, thanks to this Commonwealth’s funding, include the refurbishing and repainting of the Avoca State School in Bundaberg with $50,000 of funding; the creation of a new playground at the Sharon State School, which is able to proceed after receiving $33,000 from the Commonwealth; a new undercover area and playground as well as refrigerative airconditioning at the Wongarra State School, courtesy of a grant of $50,000; almost $30,000 worth of new floor covering for the Gladstone State High School; $50,000 worth of IT equipment for students to use at the Tannum Sands State High School; and a complete upgrade of playground equipment and a new school bus for the disabled kids of the Rosella Park School in Gladstone—a very special school, I might add—thanks to $73,000 from the Commonwealth.

These are the sorts of projects that, though often desperately needed by schools, never make it into the priority lists of state government authorities. Normally they remain on schools’ wish lists, unless P&Cs themselves are able to raise the money to do the work. The situation has not been helped by the fact that, under the Beattie government, each Queensland student receives nearly $600 a year less than the national average for students at state schools. On the other hand, the Australian government has increased funding to Queensland state schools and students to $603 million in 2005-06. This is an increase of around $43 million, or 7.6 per cent, over the past year and of $313 million, or 108 per cent, since we took office in 1996.

On another positive note, I would like to pass on my congratulations to two outstanding young science students at St Luke’s Anglican School in Bundaberg: Luke Aaron and Julia Sullivan. Both Luke and Julia are in year 10 and have achieved a place in the highest ranks of the 2005 National Chemistry Quiz, coming in the top half per cent of entrants. More than 11,000 Queensland students took part in the quiz, with only 56 achieving the same or a better score than Luke and Julia. This is a fortnight when Australians from Perth have taken out the Nobel Prize for work on ulcers and another team from Brisbane has found a vaccine for cervical cancer, and these young people have a proud tradition to follow as their careers develop.

In the minute or two remaining, I commiserate with the member for Werriwa in his complaint about the Sydney City Council not honouring the Wests Tigers. Teams that make it to the Australian Rugby League grand final deserve recognition. The Wests Tigers and the Cowboys defied the odds and the critics and presented Australia with a very entertaining match. I congratulate both teams. I love watching the open play of the Cowboys; I think they are a marvellous team. Let me say to the Lord Mayor of Sydney that this would never have happened if the Broncos had won in Brisbane or the Cowboys had won in Townsville.
Question agreed to.

How many PBS prescriptions were filled for people who did not hold concession cards during (a) 2003-2004, and (b) 2004-2005 in (i) Victoria, and (ii) the electoral division of Scullin.

How many PBS prescriptions were filled for people who did not hold concession cards during (a) 2003-2004, and (b) 2004-2005 in the postcode area (i) 3074, (ii) 3075, (iii) 3076, (iv) 3082, (v) 3083, (vi) 3087, (vii) 3088, (viii) 3089, (ix) 3090, (x) 3091, and (xi) 3752.

How many PBS prescriptions were filled for scripts that cost the consumer a maximum of $3.80 during (a) 2003-2004, and (b) 2004-2005 in the postcode area (i) 3074, (ii) 3075, (iii) 3076, (iv) 3082, (v) 3083, (vi) 3087, (vii) 3088, (viii) 3089, (ix) 3090, (x) 3091, and (xi) 3752.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing
talker.name: Mr Abbott

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Government is not considering removing branded pharmaceuticals from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
The total number of PBS subsidised prescriptions filled in Victoria and the electoral division of Scullin during 2003-2004 and 2004-2005 are as follows:

Please note: The above statistics are based on PBS prescription categories including general prescriptions, concession prescriptions, Doctors Bag and PBS Safety Net prescriptions. The statistics include PBS prescriptions that were issued after the patients had reached their safety net threshold. The statistics do not include PBS medicines dispensed at prices less than the mandatory co-payments.

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is the Commonwealth Electoral Division. In your question, you requested data for numerous postcodes that are wholly or partially contained within the electoral division of Scullin. I have provided the information for this electoral division in question two.
The total number of PBS subsidised prescriptions for concession card holders, in Victoria and the electoral division of Scullin during 2003-2004 and 2004-2005 are as follows:

Please note: The above statistics are based on concession card holders and do not include Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme (RPBS) card holders. The above statistics include PBS prescriptions that were issued after the patients had reached their safety net threshold.

The smallest geographical area for which the Department routinely produces statistics is the Commonwealth Electoral Division. In your question, you requested data for numerous postcodes that are wholly or partially contained within the electoral division of Scullin. I have provided the information for this Electoral Division in question four.
The total number of PBS subsidised prescriptions for non concession card holders in Victoria and the electoral division of Scullin, during 2003-2004 and 2004-2005, are as follows:

Please note: The above statistics include PBS prescriptions that were issued after the patients had reached the safety net threshold. The statistics do not include PBS medicines dispensed at prices less than the mandatory co-payment.

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is the Commonwealth Electoral Division. In your question, you requested data for numerous postcodes that are wholly or partially contained within the electoral division of Scullin. I have provided the information for this electoral division in question six.
The total number of PBS subsidised prescriptions that cost the consumer a maximum of $23.70* in Victoria and the electoral division of Scullin during 2003-2004 and 2004-2005 are as follows:

* Note: Co-payment amounts for general patients (non-concession card holders) were $23.10 in 2003, $23.70 in 2004 and are $28.60 in 2005. The above figures always reflect the general co-payment amount at any given point in time. The statistics do not include PBS medicines dispensed at prices less than the mandatory co-payment.

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is the Commonwealth Electoral Division. In your question, you requested data for numerous postcodes that are wholly or partially contained within the electoral division of Scullin. I have provided the information for this electoral division in question eight.
The total number of PBS subsidised prescriptions that cost the consumer a maximum of $3.80* in Victoria and the electoral division of Scullin during 2003-2004 and 2004-2005 are as follows:

* Note: Co-payment amounts for concession card holders were $3.70 in 2003, $3.80 in 2004 and are $4.60 in 2005. The above figures always reflect the concessional co‑payment amount at any given point in time. No PBS medicines are dispensed at less than the concessional co-payment amount, unless they are provided as safety net entitlements (ie. at no charge for concessional patients).

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is the Commonwealth Electoral Division. In your question, you requested data for numerous postcodes that are wholly or partially contained within the electoral division of Scullin. I have provided the information for this electoral division in question ten.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 7 December 2004:

item.para: Does the Royal Australian Air Force and/or the Department of Defence maintain records of the food and beverages purchased for and consumed on Special Purpose Flights.
Do these records indicate the quantities of food and/or beverages consumed on individual Special Purpose Flights.
For how long are these records retained.

talker.name: Kelly, De-Anne, MP
talker.role: Minister for Veterans’ Affairs
talker.name: Mrs De-Anne Kelly

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Yes, No. 34 Squadron holds paper-based records for food and beverages supplied for each flight, and on completion of the task, all unconsumed beverages and unopened packaged food.
See above.
Records are retained for six years.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: Is the Government considering removing branded pharmaceuticals from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) list.
How many PBS prescriptions were filled during (a) 2003-2004, and (b) 2004-2005 in (i) New South Wales, and (ii) the electoral division of Fowler.
How many PBS prescriptions were filled during (a) 2003-2004, and (b) 2004-2005 in the postcode area (i) 2163, (ii) 2165, (iii) 2166, (iv) 2168, (v) 2170, (vi) 2176, (vii) 2177.
How many PBS prescriptions were filled for concession card holders during (a) 2003-2004, and (b) 2004-2005 in (i) New South Wales, and (ii) the electoral division of Fowler.

How many PBS prescriptions were filled for concession card holders during (a) 2003-2004, and (b) 2004-2005 in the postcode area (i) 2163, (ii) 2165, (iii) 2166, (iv) 2168, (v) 2170, (vi) 2176, (vii) 2177.
How many PBS prescriptions were filled for people who did not hold concession cards during (a) 2003-2004, and (b) 2004-2005 in (i) New South Wales, and (ii) the electoral division of Fowler.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing
talker.name: Mr Abbott

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Government is not considering removing branded pharmaceuticals from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
The total number of PBS subsidised prescriptions filled in New South Wales and the electoral division of Fowler during 2003-2004 and 2004-2005 are as follows:

Please note: The above statistics are based on PBS prescription categories including general prescriptions, concession prescriptions, Doctors Bag and PBS Safety Net prescriptions. The statistics include PBS prescriptions that were issued after the patients had reached their safety net threshold. The statistics do not include PBS medicines dispensed at prices less than the mandatory co-payments.

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is the Commonwealth Electoral Division. In your question, you requested data for numerous postcodes that are wholly or partially contained within the electoral division of Fowler. I have provided the information for this electoral division in question two.
The total number of PBS subsidised prescriptions for concession card holders, in New South Wales and the electoral division of Fowler during 2003-2004 and 2004-2005 are as follows:

Please note: The above statistics are based on concession cardholders and do not include Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme (RPBS) card holders. The above statistics include PBS prescriptions that were issued after the patients had reached their safety net threshold.

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is the Commonwealth Electoral Division. In your question, you requested data for numerous postcodes that are wholly or partially contained within the electoral division of Fowler. I have provided the information for this electoral division in question four.
The total number of PBS subsidised prescriptions for non concession card holders in New South Wales and the electoral division of Fowler, during 2003-2004 and 2004-2005, are as follows:

Please note: The above statistics include PBS prescriptions that were issued after the patients had reached the safety net threshold. The statistics do not include PBS medicines dispensed at prices less than the mandatory co-payment.

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is the Commonwealth Electoral Division. In your question, you requested data for numerous postcodes that are wholly or partially contained within the electoral division of Fowler. I have provided the information for this electoral division in question six.
The total number of PBS subsidised prescriptions that cost the consumer a maximum of $23.70* in New South Wales and the electoral division of Fowler during 2003-2004 and 2004-2005 are as follows:

* Note: Co-payment amounts for general patients (non-concession card holders) were $23.10 in 2003, $23.70 in 2004 and are $28.60 in 2005. The above figures always reflect the general co-payment amount at any given point in time. The statistics do not include PBS medicines dispensed at prices less than the mandatory co-payment.

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is the Commonwealth Electoral Division. In your question, you requested data for numerous postcodes that are wholly or partially contained within the electoral division of Fowler. I have provided the information for this electoral division in question eight.
The total number of PBS subsidised prescriptions that cost the consumer a maximum of $3.80* in New South Wales and the electoral division of Fowler during 2003-2004 and 2004-2005 are as follows:

* Note: Co-payment amounts for concession card holders were $3.70 in 2003, $3.80 in 2004 and are $4.60 in 2005. The above figures always reflect the concessional co‑payment amount at any given point in time. No PBS medicines are dispensed at less than the concessional co-payment amount, unless they are provided as safety net entitlements (ie. at no charge for concessional patients).

The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is the Commonwealth Electoral Division. In your question, you requested data for numerous postcodes that are wholly or partially contained within the electoral division of Fowler. I have provided the information for this electoral division in question ten.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

quote.para: What is the Government’s response to the rapid increase of higher density redevelopment in Brisbane’s CBD and the increasing problems it is having on interference with television reception due to shadowing.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: Planning and interference issues relating to television services are the responsibility of an independent statutory body, the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA).

The regulation of urban planning and development is primarily a matter for State Government and municipal authorities. ACMA is aware of the potential impact of urban and high rise development on the reception of television and radio services and has urged local councils to take these issues into account when considering development proposals submitted for council approval. However, ACMA cannot compel councils to do so.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

quote.para: In respect of the container ship, the Pacific Quest, whose owners were recently fined for discharging oily waste on the Great Barrier Reef in 2002, (a) was the ship operating under a single or continuous voyage permit at the time of the spill, (b) has the ship carried coastal cargo under a single or continuous voyage permit at any time, (c) are any other ships owned by the owners of the Pacific Quest, Mattrim Marine Inc., currently operating under a single or continuous voyage permit, and (d) is the Government considering amending its shipping policy to ensure that foreign-owned ships are not able to compromise the pristine marine environment on the Australian coast.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr Truss

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: No.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Yes.

item.label: (c)
item.para: No other ships owned by Mattrim Marine Inc. are currently operating under a single or continuous voyage permit.

item.label: (d)
item.para: The Government has implemented a range of measures consistent with international agreements to minimise the risks from all shipping to the marine environment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

quote.para: Has the Government received any correspondence from the British Government notifying it of the removal or intention to remove British troops from Iraq; if so, (a) on what date was it received; and (b) has the Government developed a contingency plan to compensate for the loss of helicopter, artillery and logistics support that is currently provided by British forces.

talker.name: Kelly, De-Anne, MP
talker.role: Minister for Veterans’ Affairs
talker.name: Mrs De-Anne Kelly

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: The Government communicates regularly with the British Government regarding its intentions in Iraq. It is not appropriate to report publicly on British positions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 17 August 2005:

item.para: What sum was awarded under the Volunteering Small Equipment Grant in 2005.
How many grants were made under the program in 2005.
What was the name, postal address and electorate of each organisation that received a grant in 2005.
How many unsuccessful applications for grants were received from each Commonwealth electoral division.
In respect of each successful application, (a) what sum was granted and (b) for what purpose was the grant awarded.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
talker.role: Minister for Human Services
talker.name: Mr Hockey

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Funding of $3 million was awarded under the Volunteer Small Equipment Grant (VSEG) Program in 2005.
2131 VSEG grants were approved in 2005.
The name and electorate of each organisation approved for a VSEG grant in 2005 is provided at Attachment A. The postal addresses cannot be disclosed due to privacy reasons and have not been provided.
Attachment A has been provided to the member.
8152 unsuccessful applications were received from 150 Commonwealth electoral divisions in 2005. Details for each electoral division is provided at Attachment B.
Attachment B has been provided to the member.
The (a) sum granted, and (b) purpose granted, for each of the approved VSEG applications is provided at Attachment A.
Attachment A has been provided to the member.

quote.para: Attachment A
2005 Volunteer Small Equipment Grants - Details of successful applications

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, in writing, on 18 August 2005:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 1590, what is the breakdown of judges and magistrates who are still presiding members of the judiciary and what is the breakdown of Federal and State Courts of those judges who are still presiding members of the judiciary.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Brough

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: 15 of the 25 members of the judiciary who had overdue income tax returns (as at February 2005) are presiding members of the judiciary as at August 2005. There are no outstanding income tax returns for presiding members of the judiciary as at 15 August 2005.
The numbers of presiding judges and magistrates who had 2003 income tax returns overdue as at February 2005 were as follows
The breakdown by Federal and State Courts of judges and magistrates that had 2003 income tax returns overdue as at February 2005 was as follows: (all have lodged as at 15 August 2005)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

item.para: Did the Australian Taxation Office engage Hewsons Australia to provide executive coaching services at a cost of $19,800; if so, what services are being provided by Hewsons Australia under the terms of this contract.
Which managers are receiving coaching and what form does the coaching take.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Brough

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes the ATO did engage the services of Hewsons Australia. The maximum possible value of the services provided is $19,800 inc GST.

I do not intend to name individual ATO officers but I can confirm that there are currently 3 staff members at the Executive Level 2 level involved in the coaching. The coaching takes on the form of 10 sessions of 1.5 hours with the participants focused on addressing identified development needs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

item.para: Did the Australian Taxation Office engage Strategic Communications Australia to provide professional writing services at a cost of $23,977; if so, what is Strategic Communications writing under the terms of this contract.
Why was it considered that Tax Office staff did not have adequate skills to write what is being written under this contract.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Brough

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes. The Australian Taxation Office engaged the services of Strategic Communications, at a cost of $23,977, to scope and prepare a draft of an Employee Handbook which is designed to provide Australian Taxation Office staff with a single, clear, authoritative summary of corporate policy and procedures.
The Australian Taxation Office did not have the available resources to provide technical writing skills at short notice to deliver this project to the timelines set.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

quote.para: Did the Australian Taxation Office engage The Leader Factor Pty Ltd at a cost of $11,500 to conduct executive coaching services; if so, what are the names of the executives who participated in this program and what form did the coaching take.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Brough

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes the ATO did engage the services of The Leader Factor Pty Ltd. The maximum possible value of the services provided is $11,550 inc GST.

I do not intend to name individual ATO officers but I can confirm that there are currently 2 staff members at the Executive Level 2 level involved in the coaching. The coaching takes on the form of 10 sessions of 1.5 hours with the participants focused on addressing identified development needs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

quote.para: Did the Australian Taxation Office engage United KFPW HR Services Pty Ltd at a cost of $12,375 to conduct executive coaching services; if so, what are the names of the executives who participated in this program and what form did the coaching take.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Brough

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes the ATO did engage the services of United KFPW HR Services Pty Ltd. The maximum possible value of the services provided is $12,375 inc GST.

I do not intend to name individual ATO officers but I can confirm that there are currently 3 staff members at the Executive Level 2 level involved in the coaching. The coaching takes on the form of 10 sessions of 1.5 hours with the participants focused on addressing identified development needs.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

quote.para: What was the total Government expenditure on the attempted prosecution of Mr Petroulias?

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
talker.role: Attorney-General
talker.name: Mr Ruddock

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The prosecution of Mr Petroulias is being conducted by the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions (CDPP) and the total cost to the CDPP including salaries for CDPP staff and associated overheads was $1,661,493 as at 7 September 2005.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

item.para: Has he read the article by Sherrie Gossett titled ‘Persecution of Kosovo Christians Said To Reveal Larger Threat’ in CNS News on 20 August 2005.

How many Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel are currently undergoing attachments or long-term postings with the armed forces of the USA and the UK, including Exercise LONGLOOK, but excluding exchanges to defence or military teaching establishments such as the UK Staff College.
To which units in the UK armed forces are ADF personnel currently attached.
How many ADF personnel are serving in a military or observer capacity with United Nations (UN) forces in the Balkans in areas which were formerly part of Yugoslavia.

How many ADF personnel are serving with the UN, UK, US or other military forces in Kosovo or the regions surrounding Kosovo and, of these, what ADF personnel are deployed in the UNMIK Kosovo region and any other region of former Yugoslavia.

What is the Government’s position on the reported attacks and desecration of an estimated 150 Christian churches, monasteries and religious residencies in Kosovo; if the Government does not have a position, when will it formulate one.
Can he say whether the construction of an estimated 200 new mosques is being funded by Wahhabist nations.
Can he confirm that over 18,000 legal complaints have been lodged accusing Albanian-backed attacks of confiscating Christian church property for the Government.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Downer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: I am aware of the contents of the article.
Please refer to the Minister for Defence.
Please refer to the Minister for Defence.
Please refer to the Minister for Defence.
Please refer to the Minister for Defence.

The Australian Government strongly condemns all destruction of religious sites and property that has occurred in Kosovo in recent years, and urges all concerned parties to ensure the appropriate restoration and rebuilding of damaged and destroyed sites.

In the late 1990s it is estimated that over 200 mosques were destroyed or damaged in Kosovo. As stated, the Australian Government strongly condemns all destruction of religious sites and property that has occurred. The figure quoted of 200 new mosques being built is likely to include the restoration and repair of the existing mosques. There are fewer entirely new mosques being constructed. I understand that UNMIK has funds for assisting with religious sites, but progress has stalled due to the unstable political situation. Some funding for the building and repair of some mosques has been from Wahhabist NGOs, and this has been the subject of some controversy within the Kosovo Muslim community.

Regularisation of property ownership is a major problem in Kosovo, particularly due to the destruction of documents and dispossession of property by both Serbs and Albanians during in the 1998-2000 conflict. There are undoubtedly large numbers of claims of various kinds made by numerous institutions and individuals. I am not in a position to verify exact numbers of these complaints lodged with Kosovo authorities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

item.para: What programmes are administered under the ‘Support for New Apprenticeships’ appropriation in output 2.2 in the Department of Education, Science and Training budget for 2005-2006.
What is the actual annual expenditure since 1998 on each of the programs identified in part (1) and what is the budgeted expenditure over the forward estimates period.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr Hardgrave

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The New Apprenticeships Incentive Programme is the only Programme administered under the ‘Support for New Apprenticeships’ appropriation in output 2.2 in the Department of Education, Science and Training budget for 2005-2006. The Programme administers the payment of financial incentives to employers and personal benefits to New Apprentices.

Departmental systems only enable the Department to provide expenditure data back to the 1999-2000 financial year. Actual annual expenditure for the New Apprenticeships Incentives Programme from 1999-2000 is:
Expenditure in $(m)
The estimated expenditure for the New Apprenticeships Incentives Programme for the Budget year and forward estimates period is:
Expenditure in $(m)

talk.start.para: asked Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Sport, in writing, on 8 September 2005:

quote.para: What are the names and positions of the persons who will represent Australia at the regional preparatory conference (Asia) which will be held from 23-25 November 2005 in Seoul in preparation for the World Conference on Arts Education, Building Creative Capacities for the 21st Century, in Lisbon from 6-9 March 2006.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Arts and Sport has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: The Australian delegation to the UNESCO Asia-Pacific Regional Conference in Preparation for the World Conference on Arts Education will comprise senior officials from the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts and the Australia Council for the Arts and a senior academic in arts education from the University of Melbourne.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, in writing, on 14 September 2005:

item.para: Did the Australian Taxation Office engage McLeod Marketing and Management to provide writing and editing services at a cost $10,230 for one project and $12,650 for another project; if so, what services were provided by McLeod Marketing and Management under the terms of these contracts.
Why was it considered necessary to engage an outside firm to write whatever was written in terms of these contracts.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Brough

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes, the Australian Taxation Office engaged McLeod Marketing and Management to provide writing and editing services. The first, at a cost of $10,230, was for day-to-day editorial review for web publishing. The second, at a cost of $12,650, was for a Panel member to work on site between 25 July and 28 August 2005 covering work that would normally have been undertaken by Tax Office staff.

It was necessary to engage a member of the Communication Services Panel Contract to meet overflow requirements at the time. While the relevant skills and resources are available within the Tax Office, they were deployed to other functions and projects.
